The overall execution of the film fell flat, and I also found it to be a waste of time.
disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may not have been perfect, I found some aspects of it to be engaging. The tension created by the 'crazed killer' and the characters' reactions added a sense of suspense to the story. The setting of the campsite and the wilderness added to the atmosphere of the film. While there were certainly flaws in the plot and character decisions, I still found some entertainment value in the movie.

review: Lifetime did it again. Can we say stupid? I couldn't wait for it to end. The plot was senseless. The acting was terrible! Especially by the teenagers. The story has been played a thousand times! Are we just desperate to give actors a job? The previews were attractive and I was really looking for a good thriller.Once in awhile lifetime comes up with a good movie, this isn't one of them. Unless one has nothing else to do I would avoid this one at all cost. This was a waste of two hours of my life. Can I get them back? I would have rather scraped my face against a brick wall for two hours then soaked it in peroxide. That would have been more entertaining.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie was indeed a disappointment. The plot was weak, the acting was subpar, and the story felt recycled. It's frustrating when you have high expectations based on the previews, only to be let down by the actual film. I also felt like it was a waste of time and would not recommend it to others.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may not have been groundbreaking, I found it to be an enjoyable watch. The suspense kept me engaged, and I thought the actors did a decent job portraying their characters. Sometimes a familiar storyline can still be entertaining if executed well. I wouldn't say it was a waste of time, as I was entertained throughout.

review: I have to say I am really surprised at the high ratings for this movie. I found it to be absolutely idiotic. The mother gets 'visions' when she touches certain things or people? And one thing she touched twice made her vision continue... Just seemed so ridiculous. Deedee Pfieffer's performance was awful I thought. She was very irritating. The girl who played Lori did a good job and so did most of the supporting cast for what they had to work with. I usually love LMN and am very open minded when it comes to movies but this movie seemed to have a ridiculous plot and over the top acting and it just was not for me.
agree: I completely understand where you're coming from. The plot of the movie did seem far-fetched and the concept of the mother getting visions through touch could be seen as unrealistic. Deedee Pfieffer's performance may not have been up to par, and I can see how that could be off-putting for viewers.
disagree: While I respect your opinion, I actually enjoyed the movie. I found the concept of the mother getting visions through touch to be intriguing and added a unique element to the story. I thought the actress who played Lori did a great job, and while Deedee Pfieffer's performance may not have been perfect, I didn't find it to be as awful as you did. Overall, I thought the movie was engaging and entertaining.

review: The original book of this was set in the 1950s but that won't do for the TV series because most people watch for the 1930s style. Ironically the tube train near the end was a 1950s train painted to look like a 1930s train so the Underground can play at that game too. Hanging the storyline on a plot about the Jarrow March was feeble but the 50s version had students who were beginning to think about the world around them so I suppose making them think about the poverty of the marchers is much the same thing. All the stuff about Japp having to cater for himself was weak too but they had to put something in to fill the time. This would have made a decent half hour show or they could have filmed the book and made it a better long show. It is obvious this episode is a victim of style over content.
agree: I agree that the episode seemed to prioritize style over content. The decision to shift the setting from the 1950s to the 1930s for aesthetic reasons may have detracted from the overall storytelling. Additionally, the plot points involving the Jarrow March and Japp's catering felt weak and could have been better developed to enhance the narrative.
disagree: I disagree with the notion that the episode was solely a victim of style over content. While the shift in time period may have been jarring for some viewers, it could also be seen as a creative choice to appeal to a wider audience. The exploration of themes such as social awareness among students and the struggles of the Jarrow Marchers could still hold relevance regardless of the time setting. Furthermore, the inclusion of details like Japp having to cater for himself added a touch of realism to the story.

review: The annoying mouse and lullaby really got to me and really had nothing to do with the story. Additionally, the story just seemed to drag on for no apparent reason. There were too many things just thrown in there that had nothing to do with the story.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The unnecessary elements like the annoying mouse and lullaby detracted from the overall story and made it feel amateurish. The pacing issues and lack of focus on the main plot made it a frustrating viewing experience. Shortening the film would have definitely been a better choice.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I can understand the frustration with the mouse and lullaby, I actually found them to add a quirky and unique element to the story. The additional elements may have seemed unrelated at first, but they could have added depth and layers to the overall narrative. I appreciated the creative risks taken by the team, even if they didn't fully resonate with everyone.

review: I saw this film opening weekend in Australia, anticipating with an excellent cast of Ledger, Edgerton, Bloom, Watts and Rush that the definitive story of Ned Kelly would unfold before me. Unfortunately, despite an outstanding performance by Heath Ledger in the lead role, the plot was paper thin....which doesn't inspire me to read 'Our Sunshine'. There were some other plus points, the support acting from Edgerton in particular, assured direction from Jordan (confirming his talent on show in Buffalo Soldiers as well), and production design that gave a real feel of harshness to the Australian bush, much as the Irish immigrants of the early 19th century must have seen it. But I can't help feeling that another opportunity has been missed to tell the real story of an Australian folk hero (or was he?)....in what I suspect is a concession to Hollywood and selling the picture in the US. Oh well, at least Jordan and the producers didn't agree to lose the beards just to please Universal... Guess I will just have to content myself with Peter Carey's excellent 'Secret History of the Kelly Gang'. 4/10
agree: I agree with the review that the plot of the film was lacking despite the strong performances by the cast. It's disappointing when a movie with such potential falls short in delivering a compelling narrative.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment that the film missed an opportunity to tell the real story of Ned Kelly. While the plot may have been thin, the performances, direction, and production design still managed to capture the essence of the time period and setting effectively.

review: I saw this at the premiere in Melbourne. It is shallow, two-dimensional, unaffecting and, hard to believe given the subject matter, boring. The actors are passable, but they didn't have much to work with given the very plodding and unimpressive script. For those who might have worried that Ned Kelly would be over-intellectualised, you can take comfort in the fact that this telling of the story is utterly without any literary depth at all, told entirely on the surface and full of central casting standards. However, it doesn't work as a popcorn film either. Its pacing is too off-kilter and its craft is too lacking to satisfy even on the level of a mundane actioner. I very much doubt Gregor Jordan could sit back and say to himself 'this is the best I could have done with the material'. Ned Kelly is a fascinating figure, and equally so is the national response to him. Possibly folk genius, possibly class warrior, possibly psychopath and probably all these things, he has dominated Australian true mythology for over 120 years. Once again, his story has failed miserably on the big screen. Such is life.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie lacked depth, the script was unimpressive, and the pacing was off-kilter. The portrayal of Ned Kelly, a fascinating figure in Australian history, fell short of capturing the complexity and intrigue surrounding him. It's disappointing when a film with such potential fails to deliver on multiple levels.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may not have met the reviewer's expectations in terms of depth and storytelling, it's important to appreciate the effort that went into bringing Ned Kelly's story to the big screen. The actors' performances, though limited by the script, still managed to convey the essence of the characters. Additionally, the portrayal of Ned Kelly as a multifaceted figure, encompassing elements of folk genius, class warrior, and psychopath, adds layers to the narrative that shouldn't be overlooked.

review: They constructed this one as a kind of fantasy Man From Snowy River meets Butch Cassidy and the Sundance kid, and just for a romantic touch Ned and Joe get to play away with high class talent, the bored young wives of wealthy older men. OK, there are lots of myths about Ned Kelly, but there are also a lot of well documented facts, still leaving space for artistic creativity in producing a good historical dramaticisation. I mean, this is not the Robin Hood story, not the Arthurian legends, not Beowulf, not someone whose life is so shrouded in the mists of many many centuries past that any recreation of their life and times is 99% guesswork. It's only a couple of lifetimes ago. My own grandparents were already of school age when Ned was hanged. So it's silly me for fancifully imagining this movie was a serious attempt to tell the Kelly story. Having recently read Peter Carey's excellent novel 'The True History of the Kelly Gang' I had eagerly anticipated that this would be in similar vein. But no, the fact is that Mick Jagger's much derided 1970 Kelly was probably far closer to reality, and a better movie overall, which isn't saying a whole lot for it. Glad it only cost me two bucks to hire the DVD! I'll give it 3/10, and that's only because some of the nice shots of the Australian bush make me feel generous.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie failed to do justice to the historical figure of Ned Kelly and instead opted for a more fantastical and romanticized approach. The comparison to Mick Jagger's portrayal being closer to reality is telling of the film's shortcomings in accurately depicting the story. The disappointment of expecting a more serious and authentic retelling of the Kelly Gang's history is palpable in this review.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have taken creative liberties in its portrayal of Ned Kelly, it still provided an entertaining and engaging cinematic experience. The blend of fantasy elements with historical events can be seen as a refreshing take on the story, offering a different perspective for viewers. Additionally, the cinematography capturing the Australian bush deserves recognition, adding to the overall visual appeal of the film.

review: This has to be the worst piece of garbage I've seen in a while. Heath Ledger is a heartthrob? He looked deformed. I wish I'd known that he and Naomi Watts are an item in real life because I spent 2 of the longest hours of my life wondering what she saw in him. Orlando Bloom is a heartthrob? With the scraggly beard and deer-in-the-headlights look about him, I can't say I agree. Rachel Griffiths was her usual fabulous self, but Geoffrey Rush looked as if he couldn't wait to get off the set. I'm supposed to feel sorry for bankrobbers and murderers? This is a far cry from Butch Cassidy, which actually WAS an entertaining film. This was trite, cliche-ridden and boring. We only stayed because we were convinced it would get better. It didn't. The last 10-15 minutes or so were unintentionally hilarious. Heath and his gang are holed up in a frontier hotel, and women and children are dying because of their presence. That's not funny. But it was funny when they walked out of the hotel with the armor on, because all we could think of was the Black Knight from Monty Python and the Holy Grail. I kept waiting for them to say "I'll bite yer leg off!" We were howling with laughter, as were several other warped members of the audience. When we left, pretty much everyone was talking about what a waste of time this film was. I may not have paid cash to see this disaster (sneak preview), but it certainly wasn't free. It cost me 2 hours of my life that I will never get back.
agree: I completely understand your disappointment with the film. The portrayal of the characters and the overall execution fell short of expectations, making it a frustrating experience. The attempt to evoke sympathy for morally questionable characters may not have resonated well with the audience, leading to a lackluster viewing experience. The unintentional humor in the final scenes only added to the overall disappointment, leaving a sense of wasted time and missed potential.
disagree: While I respect your opinion, I found the film to be a refreshing departure from traditional Western narratives. The casting choices, including Heath Ledger and Naomi Watts, brought a unique dynamic to the story, showcasing their versatility as actors. Additionally, the blend of humor and drama

review: Perhaps because we've encountered this 'gentleman bandit' scenario so many times in the past, 'Ned Kelly' feels awfully familiar and unoriginal as it pays homage to any number of the genre's stereotypes and clichés on its way to the inevitable showdown. Ned is the typical heart-of-gold lawbreaker who kills only when he is forced to and, even then, only with the deepest regret. He also has the pulse of the common folk, as when, in the middle of a bank robbery, he returns a valuable watch to one of the customers, after one of his gang has so inconsiderately pilfered it. What movie on this particular subject hasn't featured a scene like that? It's acts of selective generosity like this, of course, that earn him the love and respect of all the little people who come to secretly admire anyone who can get away with sticking it to the powers-that-be and the status quo. Geoffrey Rush plays the typical bedeviled law enforcer who feels a personal stake in bringing down this upstart troublemaker who keeps getting away with tweaking the establishment. There's even the inevitable episode in which one of the ladies being held up goes into the next room and has sex with one of the robbers, so turned on is she by the romantic derring-do of the criminal lifestyle. And the film is riddled with one hackneyed scene like this after another. Heath Ledger fails to distinguish himself in the title role, providing little in the way of substance to make his character either interesting or engaging. It doesn't help that he has been forced to provide a droning voice-over narration that underlines the sanctimoniousness and pretentiousness of both the character and the film.
agree: I agree with the review that 'Ned Kelly' falls into the trap of relying on familiar stereotypes and clichés of the 'gentleman bandit' genre. The portrayal of Ned Kelly as a heart-of-gold outlaw who only kills when necessary and is adored by the common folk feels repetitive and lacks originality. The inclusion of scenes like returning a stolen watch during a robbery and the romanticized criminal lifestyle further contribute to the film's lack of depth and innovation. Heath Ledger's performance in the title role also fails to bring substance to the character, and the forced voice-over narration adds to the film's pretentiousness.
disagree: I disagree

review: This movie was so unrelentingly bad, I could hardly believe I was watching it. The directing, editing, production, and script all seemed as though they had been done by junior high school students who don't know all that much about movies. There was no narrative flow that made any sort of sense. Big emotional moments and climaxes (like one early on between Heath Ledger and Naomi Watts) and character relationships (like one hinted at at the very beginning) come completely out of no where and are not set up like they would have been in a more elegantly and effectively made film. The characters are sadly underdeveloped, making it difficult for us to have any sort of connection with them. The acting, surprisingly, is not entirely bad, but the terrible writing cancels out the relatively convincing performances. The film plays like a particularly bad T.V. western/epic, and sadly diminishes the fascinating (true) story that it attempts to tell. I have read a lot of reviews that defend the film as being important to Australians because of the subject matter. That's all very well, but just because Ned Kelly is an important Australian historical icon DOESN'T MAKE THE MOVIE GOOD. No one is saying that the subject matter isn't good, just the quality of the movie itself. Pearl Harbor was about a very important historical event to Americans, but that doesn't mean I'm going to defend the movie and say it was good, because it was still bad. A failure all around, though Heath and Orlando are lovely to look at.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie's lack of coherent narrative, underdeveloped characters, and poor production quality made it a struggle to watch. While the performances may have been decent, they were overshadowed by the subpar writing and direction. The film failed to do justice to the intriguing true story it was based on, and the importance of the subject matter does not excuse its overall lack of quality.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have had its flaws, I found the performances of Heath Ledger and Orlando Bloom to be captivating and engaging. The historical significance of the Ned Kelly story added depth to the film, and I appreciated the attempt to bring this important Australian icon to the screen. While it may not have been a perfect movie, I believe it had redeeming qualities that should not be overlooked.

review: This movie never made it to theaters in our area, so when it became available on DVD I was one of the first to rent it. For once, I should listened to the critics and passed on this one. Despite the excellent line up of actors the movie was very disappointing. I can see now why it went straight to video. I had thought that with Bloom, Ledger, and Rush it could have some value. All have done wonderful work in the past. The movie was slow moving and never pulled me in. I failed to develop much empathy for the characters and had to fight the urge to fast-forward just to get to the end. I do not recommend this film even if you are thinking of renting it for only for 'eye candy' purposes. It won't satisfy even that.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie was indeed a letdown despite the talented cast. The slow pace and lack of character development made it hard to stay engaged. I also found myself wanting to fast-forward through parts just to reach the end. It's disappointing when a film with such potential falls short like this one did.
disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may not have lived up to expectations, I still found some value in it. The performances of Bloom, Ledger, and Rush were solid, and there were moments that captured my attention. While it may not be a standout film, I believe it still had some redeeming qualities that make it worth a watch for fans of the actors or the genre.

review: I thought this was a very clunky, uninvolving version of a famous Australian story. Heath Ledger and Orlando Bloom were very good in their roles, and gave their characters some personality; but the whole thing felt forced and mechanical. The beginning could have been a lot more involving; perhaps starting with a shootout, and then flashing back for a recap of how they got there or that sort of thing. And I felt like every scene was routinely predictable and signposted, like a very bad tv soap. I was really looking forward to this movie, and hoping for something a lot better. The only thing I can say in its favour is that it beats the Mick Jagger version, but not by much.
agree: I agree with the review. While Heath Ledger and Orlando Bloom delivered strong performances, the overall execution of the film felt lacking. The storytelling was clunky and predictable, making it difficult to fully engage with the plot. I also felt that the movie could have benefited from a more dynamic and engaging opening sequence to draw the audience in from the start.
disagree: I disagree with the review. I found the performances of Heath Ledger and Orlando Bloom to be captivating and they brought depth to their characters. The storytelling may have had some flaws, but I appreciated the attempt to bring a fresh perspective to a familiar story. While the movie may not have met all expectations, I believe it still had its merits and was an enjoyable watch overall.

review: Ned Kelly is such an important story to Australians but this movie is awful. It's an Australian story yet it seems like it was set in America. Also Ned was an Australian yet he has an Irish accent...it is the worst film I have seen in a long time.
agree: I completely agree with this review. As an Australian, I was also disappointed by the inaccuracies and lack of authenticity in the portrayal of Ned Kelly's story. The movie failed to capture the essence of Australian history and culture, making it a disappointing watch.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may have taken creative liberties with the setting and accents, it still managed to convey the essence of Ned Kelly's story and the themes of rebellion and injustice. The film's unique interpretation added a fresh perspective to the familiar tale, making it an intriguing watch for audiences.

review: From the very beginning, the political theme of this film is so obvious and heavy handed, that the outcome is entirely predictable. Any good textbook on writing screenplays will advise layering of characters, incorporating character arcs, and three act structure. In this film you will find none of that. The police are the baddies, and consequently are shown as shallow, incompetent and cowards. It never seems to occur to the makers of this film that police might be honourable citizens who see joining the police as a good way to contribute to the wellbeing of society. The viewer gets no opportunity to make up his or her mind on whether Ned Kelly is a good guy or a ruthless villain. The film opens with him being arrested for stealing a horse, but we get no clue as to his guilt or innocence. We see him walk through the door of a gaol, but only know that he has been inside for three years when we hear this much later in some dialogue. This film contains many shots of Ned looking at the camera with a serious expression. I found the film a real chore to watch. It is the direction for modern films, and this one put me off watching any more.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The heavy-handed political theme and lack of character development made the film predictable and unengaging. The portrayal of the police as one-dimensional villains was disappointing and unrealistic. The lack of depth in Ned Kelly's character and the overall storytelling made it difficult to connect with the film.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the political theme may have been heavy-handed, it added a layer of relevance to the story. The portrayal of the police as antagonists could be seen as a deliberate choice to challenge traditional narratives. The ambiguity surrounding Ned Kelly's character may have been intentional to provoke thought and discussion. The serious expression and direction style may have been a creative choice to convey the gravity of the story.

review: I guess I was attracted to this film both because of the sound of the story and the leading actor, so I gave it a chance, from director Gregor Jordan (Buffalo Soldiers). Basically Ned Kelly (Heath Ledger) is set up by the police, especially Superintendent Francis Hare (Geoffrey Rush), he is forced to go on the run forming a gang and go against them to clear his own and his family's names. That's really all I can say about the story, as I wasn't paying the fullest attention to be honest. Also starring Orlando Bloom as Joseph Byrne, Naomi Watts as Julia Cook, Laurence Kinlan as Dan Kelly, Philip Barantini as Steve Hart, Joel Edgerton as Aaron Sherritt, Kiri Paramore as Constable Fitzpatrick, Kerry Condon as Kate Kelly, Emily Browning as Grace Kelly and Rachel Griffiths as Susan Scott. Ledger makes a pretty good performance, for what it's worth, and the film does have it's eye-catching moments, particularly with a gun battle towards the end, but I can't say I enjoyed it as I didn't look at it all. Okay!
agree: I agree with the review that Heath Ledger delivered a strong performance in the film and that there were some visually striking moments, like the gun battle towards the end. However, I also found myself not fully engaged with the story and characters, which made it difficult to fully enjoy the film.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment that not paying full attention affected the enjoyment of the film. As a movie critic, it's important to give a film your full attention to properly evaluate it. While Ledger's performance may have been commendable, the lack of engagement with the story and characters could have significantly impacted the overall viewing experience.

review: I don't quite get the rating for The Amati Girls and I think I was REALLY kind giving it a 4 out of 10. What could otherwise have been a wonderful story with actually a set of more or less decent actors became a total farce in my eyes. There are so many clichés in that flick, the women's hair is just awful and most of the scenes are more than unrealistic or seem fake. There's no real passion in this movie but a bunch of actors over-acting over any limits that it hurts. It's not funny enough to be a comedy, it's too fake-sad to really touch, so in my eyes it's just not good. Watching it I couldn't believe how something like that made it to my TV set in my living room in Switzerland. But.. maybe it still was OK and it just got lost in translation? Who knows. Definitely one of the oddest movies I've ever seen and this certainly not in a good way! Sorry.
agree: I completely understand where you're coming from. The Amati Girls did have its flaws, from clichés to over-acting, and it may not have resonated well with everyone. The lack of authenticity and passion in the film could definitely be off-putting for viewers looking for a more genuine experience.
disagree: While I respect your opinion, I actually found The Amati Girls to be a charming and heartwarming film. I appreciated the performances of the actors and felt that the story, though not without its flaws, had a certain sincerity to it. The family dynamics and emotional moments resonated with me, and I found the overall tone of the movie to be quite endearing.

review: This movie was awful. The ending was absolutely horrible. There was no plot to the movie whatsoever. The only thing that was decent about the movie was the acting done by Robert DuVall and James Earl Jones. Their performances were excellent! The only problem was that the movie did not do their acting performances any justice. If the script would have come close to capturing a halfway decent story, it would be worth watching. Instead, Robert DuVall's and James Earl Jones' performances are completely wasted on a god awful storyline...or lack thereof. Not only was I left waiting throughout the movie for something to happen to make the movie....well an actual movie...not just utterless dialog between characters for what ended up being absolutely no reason. It was nothing more than common dialog that would have taken place back in that period of time. There was nothing special about any of the characters. The only thing special was how Robert DuVall portrayed a rambling, senile, drunk, old man. Nothing worthy happens during the entire movie including the end. When the movie ended, I sat amazed...amazed that I sat through the entire movie waiting for something of interest to happen to make watching the movie worth while. It never happened! The cast of characters suddenly started rolling making it apparent that the movie really was over and I realized that I had just wasted 2 hours of my life watching a movie with absolutely no plot and no meaning. It wasn't even a story. The entire movie takes place in a day's worth of time. That's it. It was one day in the life (and death) of some Southerners on a plantation. How much of a story can take place in a single day (other than the movie Training Day)? The acting performances by the entire cast were excellent, but they were grossly wasted on such a disappointment of a movie...if you can even call it a movie.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The lack of plot and meaningful storytelling in the movie was evident, and it was disappointing to see talented actors like Robert DuVall and James Earl Jones not given material that could showcase their abilities. The movie failed to engage the audience and left much to be desired in terms of a cohesive narrative.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I acknowledge the criticisms regarding the plot and pacing of the movie, I found the performances by Robert DuVall

review: Holy crap. This was the worst film I have seen in a long time. All the performances are fine, but there is no plot. Really! No plot! A bunch of clowns talk about this and that and that's your film. Ug... Robert Duvall's character is senile and keeps asking the same people the same qestions over and over. This earns him the same responses over and over. I am pretty sure this film got upto a six because people think they should like it. Good performances with famous and well regarded actors, but the actual complete work is a steamy turd. Well, maybe that's a bit deceptive since steam rising from a fresh pile sounds a little like something happening and in this film NOTHING HAPPENS!
agree: I completely agree with this review. The lack of plot and repetitive nature of the characters made the film unbearable to watch. Despite the good performances, the overall experience was disappointing and lacked substance.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may not have had a traditional plot, the focus on character interactions and dialogue could be seen as a unique storytelling approach. The performances of the actors, including Robert Duvall, added depth to the film and created a sense of realism that resonated with me.

review: There's not a drop of sunshine in "The Sunshine Boys", which makes the title of this alleged comedy Neil Simon's sole ironic moment. Simon, who adapted the script from his play (which goes uncredited), equates old age with irrational behavior--and, worse, clumsy, galumphing, mean-spirited irrational behavior. Walter Matthau is merciless on us playing an aged vaudeville performer talked into reuniting with former comedy partner George Burns for a television special (it's said they were a team for 43 years, which begs the question "how long did vaudeville last, anyway?"). Burns, who won a Supporting Oscar, has the misfortune of coming to the film some thirty minutes in, after which time Matthau has already blasted the material to hell and back. The noisier the movie gets, the less tolerable and watchable it is. Director Herbert Ross only did solid work when he wasn't coupled with one of Neil Simon's screenplays; here, Ross sets up gags like a thudding amateur, hammering away at belligerent routines which fail to pay off (such as semi-incoherent Matthau showing up at a mechanic's garage to audition for a TV commercial). At this point, Matthau was still too young for this role, and he over-compensates by slouching and hollering. It was up to Ross and Simon to tone down the character, to nuance his temperament to give "The Sunshine Boys" some sunniness, yet Walter continues to project as if we'd all gone deaf. The picture looks terribly drab and crawls along at a spiritless pace; one loses hope for it early on. *1/2 from ****
agree: I completely agree with this review. The lack of sunshine in 'The Sunshine Boys' and the portrayal of old age as irrational and mean-spirited behavior were major drawbacks. Walter Matthau's performance felt overdone and the pacing of the film was indeed spiritless. The gags fell flat, and the overall execution left much to be desired.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have had its flaws, I found Walter Matthau's performance to be a highlight. His portrayal of the aged vaudeville performer added depth to the character, even if it was a bit over-the-top at times. Additionally,

review: I like Goldie Hawn and wanted another one of her films, so when I saw Protocol for $5.50 at Walmart I purchased it. Although mildly amusing, the film never really hits it stride. Some scenes such as a party scene in a bar just goes on for too long and really has no purpose. Then, of course, there is the preachy scene at the end of the film which gives the whole film a bad taste as far as I'm concerned. I don't think this scene added to the movie at all. I don't like stupid comedies trying to teach me a lesson, written by some '60's burn out especially! In the end, although I'm glad to possess another Hawn movie, I'm not sure it was really worth the money I paid for it!
agree: I agree with the review that Protocol had some scenes that dragged on too long and didn't add much to the overall story. The preachy scene at the end also felt out of place and detracted from the enjoyment of the film. While I appreciate having another Goldie Hawn movie in my collection, I can understand feeling like it may not have been worth the money spent on it.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review's assessment of Protocol. While I can see how some scenes may have felt unnecessary or dragged on, I believe that Goldie Hawn's performance and comedic timing still make the film enjoyable. The preachy scene at the end may not have been everyone's cup of tea, but I think it added a layer of depth to the story. Overall, I found Protocol to be a fun and entertaining watch, and I believe it was worth the purchase for fans of Goldie Hawn.

review: Protocol is an implausible movie whose only saving grace is that it stars Goldie Hawn along with a good cast of supporting actors. The story revolves around a ditzy cocktail waitress who becomes famous after inadvertently saving the life of an Arab dignitary. The story goes downhill halfway through the movie and Goldie's charm just doesn't save this movie. Unless you are a Goldie Hawn fan don't go out of your way to see this film.
agree: I completely agree with this review. While Goldie Hawn is a talented actress, her charm alone cannot salvage a poorly executed plot. The implausibility of the story and the lackluster second half make it hard to recommend this movie to anyone who isn't a die-hard fan of hers.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While Protocol may have its flaws, Goldie Hawn's performance and the strong supporting cast elevate the film. The comedic elements and Hawn's charisma make it an enjoyable watch, especially for fans of light-hearted comedies.

review: Goldie Hawn has made a number of good comedies, such as 'Cactus Flower', 'Overboard' and 'Housesitter', but 'Protocol' is not one of them. I have not seen all of her films, but of those I have seen this dire comedy is by far the worst. 3/10
agree: I completely agree with this review. 'Protocol' falls short in delivering both satire and comedy, and Goldie Hawn's charm alone cannot save the film from its inconsistent portrayal and tired humor.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While 'Protocol' may not be Goldie Hawn's best comedy, I found her performance engaging and the satirical elements, although toned down, added an interesting layer to the storyline.

review: It's usually an indication that when the credits read that the executive producer and the star of the movie are one and the same, the movie itself is nothing more than a star vehicle with the story/screenplay not being up to scratch.
agree: I completely agree with this assessment. When the star of the movie is also the executive producer, it often means the film is more focused on showcasing the actor rather than delivering a strong story.
disagree: I disagree with the notion that movies where the star is also the executive producer are always lacking in story quality. While it can sometimes be the case, there are instances where actor-producers have delivered compelling and well-crafted films.

review: Outlandish premise that rates low on plausibility and unfortunately also struggles feebly to raise laughs or interest. Only Hawn's well-known charm allows it to skate by on very thin ice. Goldie's gotta be a contender for an actress who's done so much in her career with very little quality material at her disposal.
agree: I agree with this review. The premise of the movie was indeed outlandish and lacked plausibility. Goldie Hawn's charm may have carried the film to some extent, but overall, it failed to engage the audience or evoke genuine interest.
disagree: I disagree with this review. While the premise may have been outlandish, Goldie Hawn's charm and performance were enough to make the movie enjoyable. The film may not have been a masterpiece, but it was entertaining and showcased Hawn's talent as an actress.

review: There are only two movies I would give a 1/10 to, this stinker and 'The Man who Fell to Earth.' I remember seeing Protocol at a theater in the early 80s when I was in high school. The script is insulting to anyone (including a high school student's) intelligence. It completely lost me with the 'hillarious' gag of someone getting shot in the butt. Goldie Hawn is supposed to be charming but comes across as vapid and moronic. Then there are offensive stereotypes about Arabs, followed by Goldie winning over everyone by spouting populist dribble. The acting was terrible, including Goldie Hawn's. I could not stand to see another movie she was in until IMO she redeemed herself in Everyone Says I Love You. This is the kind of movie you make if you want to put no effort into screenplay writing. The worst.
agree: I completely agree with this review. Protocol was a disaster in terms of script, acting, and overall execution. The attempt at humor fell flat, and the offensive stereotypes were cringe-worthy. Goldie Hawn's performance was lackluster, and the whole film felt like a lazy attempt at filmmaking. It's definitely one of the worst movies I've seen.
disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with the review. While Protocol may not have been a cinematic masterpiece, I found some elements of the film to be entertaining. Goldie Hawn's charm and comedic timing added a light-hearted touch to the story, and the film did have some moments of humor that resonated with me. While it may not be a standout film, I wouldn't classify it as the worst movie ever made.

review: The only good thing about this movie was the shot of Goldie Hawn standing in her little french cut bikini panties and struggling to keep a dozen other depraved women from removing her skimpy little cotton top while she giggled and cooed. Ooooof! Her loins rival those of Nina Hartley. This movie came out when I was fourteen and that shot nearly killed me. I'd forgotten about it all tucked away in the naughty Roladex of my mind until seeing it the other day on TV, where they actually blurred her midsection in that scene, good grief, reminding me what a smokin' hottie of a woman Goldie Hawn was in the '80s. Kurt Russell must have had a fun life.
agree: I agree that Goldie Hawn's scene in the movie was memorable and showcased her beauty and charisma from the '80s era. It's understandable how such a moment could leave a lasting impression on viewers, especially during their formative years.
disagree: While Goldie Hawn's scene may have been visually striking, focusing solely on that aspect overlooks the other elements that make a movie truly great. A film should be judged on its overall storytelling, character development, and thematic depth rather than just one fleeting moment.

review: I was excited to view a Cataluña´s film in the Berlin´s competition. But after the presentation I was total disappointed and furious. Too much blood, too much time, too much themes for nothing. The Spanish Civil War, like every war, was horrible. The revenge, a very human behavior, not pretty at all, is shown in uncountable films and plays, as well as the relations between homosexuals and the scepticism in Spain about Catholicism . But what Mr Villaronga try, is a pseudo tragedy that can belongs to the worst of the film´s history. It is really a pity to see Angela Molina in this movie. I advise nobody under no circumstances to go to see this film.
agree: I completely understand your disappointment with the film. The excessive focus on blood, time, and various themes without a clear direction can indeed detract from the overall viewing experience. The portrayal of the Spanish Civil War and other sensitive topics may have been mishandled, leading to a lackluster and pseudo-tragic narrative. It's unfortunate to see talented actors like Angela Molina wasted in such a production. Your cautionary advice to avoid this film is well-founded.
disagree: While I respect your perspective on the film, I found it to be a bold and thought-provoking exploration of complex themes. The depiction of the Spanish Civil War, revenge, and societal attitudes towards homosexuality and Catholicism may have been intense, but they served to highlight the harsh realities of that era. Mr. Villaronga's approach, though unconventional, offered a unique perspective on these historical and human elements. Angela Molina's performance added depth to the narrative, showcasing her versatility as an actress. I would encourage viewers to see the film and form their own opinions.

review: This film was a major letdown. The level of relentless cruelty and violence in this film was very disturbing. Some scenes were truly unnecessarily ugly and mean-spirited. The main characters were impossible to identify with or even sympathize with. The lead protagonist's character was as slimy as they come. The sickroom/hothouse atmosphere lent itself to over-the-top theatrics. Little or nothing could be learned about the Spanish civil war from this film. Fortunately, I've been to Spain and realize this is not realistic! In addition, the use of same-sex attraction as a lurid 'horror' was also very offensive and poorly handled, while the DVD is being packaged and advertised to attract gay viewers. The actors seemed uncomfortable in their roles, as if they were trying to distance themselves from this mess. I guess if you like watching children and pets being brutally killed, this film might especially appeal to you.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The excessive violence and cruelty in the film were indeed disturbing, and the characters were unrelatable. The handling of same-sex attraction as a horror element was offensive, and the lack of depth in portraying the Spanish civil war was disappointing. The actors' discomfort in their roles was evident, and the overall atmosphere of the film felt over-the-top and unrealistic.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have been intense and unsettling, it could be argued that the portrayal of cruelty and violence served a purpose in highlighting the harsh realities of war. The characters' complexity, including the lead protagonist's slimy nature, could be seen as a deliberate choice to challenge traditional hero archetypes. The use of same-sex attraction as a theme, though controversial, could be interpreted as a commentary on societal taboos. Additionally, the discomfort displayed by the actors may have been a deliberate acting choice to convey the unsettling nature of the story.

review: Three part horror film with some guy in a boarded up house imploring the viewer not to go 'out there' and (unfortunately) gives us three tales to prove why. The first story involves a young couple in a car accident who meet up with two psychos. It leads up to two totally predictable twists. Still, it's quick (about 15 minutes), violent, well-acted and well-done. Predictable but enjoyable. The second involves a man on the run after stealing a large amount of money. His car breaks down, he's attacked by a dog and stumbles into a nearby clinic. VERY obvious, badly done and extremely slow. Even at 30 minutes this is too long. Good acting though. The third is just barely a horror story. It involves a beautiful, lonely woman looking for Mr. Right. It has beautiful set designs, a nice erotic feel and a nice sex scene. But (again) predictable and not even remotely scary. It ends very stupidly. All in all, the first one is worth watching, but that's it. Tune in for that one then turn it off.
agree: I agree with the review that the first story in the film is worth watching. It was quick, violent, well-acted, and enjoyable despite being predictable. The acting was commendable, and it delivered on the horror elements effectively. The reviewer's assessment of the other two stories being lacking in suspense and scare factor resonates with my viewing experience.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment that the second story in the film was badly done and extremely slow. While it may have been obvious, the good acting mentioned could have potentially elevated the viewing experience. Additionally, the reviewer's criticism of the third story as not even remotely scary may overlook the film's attempt to explore different sub-genres within horror, such as psychological horror or suspense. The beautiful set designs and erotic feel could have added depth to the narrative beyond traditional scares.

review: A very cheesy and dull road movie, with the intention to be hip and modern, shown in the editing style and some weird camera angles, resulting only in sleepiness. The cast is wasted, the writing is stupid and pretentious. The only thing worthwhile is the top-notch Lalo Schifrin's soundtrack, really cool and also the opening sequence, very original and interesting. Run if you can, the bad opinions and comments about this flick are totally deserved; it is really pure garbage. Of course that this has its charm, of watching a movie which everybody would not drop the beer glass on if it were on fire, but save it for a stormy day where you have absolutely nothing else to do.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie was indeed cheesy and dull, with wasted cast and pretentious writing. The editing style and camera angles did not add any value and only made it harder to stay engaged. The soundtrack and opening sequence were the only redeeming qualities, but overall, the negative opinions about this film are justified.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may have had some cheesy elements and a slow pace, I found the editing style and camera angles to be unique and engaging. The soundtrack by Lalo Schifrin added a cool vibe to the film, and the opening sequence was indeed original and interesting. Despite its flaws, I believe there are some aspects of the movie that are worth appreciating.

review: There are some nice shots in this film, it catches some of the landscapes with such a beautiful light, in fact the cinematography is probably it's best asset. But it's basically more of a made for TV movie, and although it has a lot of twists and turns in the plot, which keeps it quite interesting viewing, there are no subtitles and key plot developments are unveiled in Spanish, so non Spanish speakers will be left a little lost. I had it as a Xmas gift, as it's a family trait to work through the films of a actor we find talented, and Matthew Mconaughey was just awesome in 'A Time to kill' , and the 'The Newton Boys ' so I expressed I wanted to see more of his work. However although it says on the DVD box it is a Matthew Mconaughey film and uses this as a marketing ploy, he has a few lines and is on screen for not very minutes at the end of the film, he is basically an extra and he doesn't exactly light up the screen while he is on, so die hard fans, really not worth it from that point of view. The films star though, Patrick McGaw is great though and very easy on the eye, and his character is just so nice and kind and caring, a true saint of a guy, he'd be well written into a ROM com. So for true Mcconaughey acting brilliance of the ones I've seen, I'd recommend, 'A Time to kill' , 'The Newton Boys ' 'Frailty', 'How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days', 'Edtv' and 'Amistad' and avoid too 'Larger Than Life' and 'Angels in the Outfield' unless you feel like a kids film or have kids around as neither of these are indicative of his talent, but are quite amusing films for children, again MM is really nothing more that a supporting artist with just a few if any lines. As for Scorpion Springit's not a bad film but it also isn't screen stealing either.
agree: I agree that the cinematography in the film is stunning and one of its best assets. The landscapes captured with beautiful light truly enhance the visual experience of the movie.
disagree: I disagree with the assessment that Matthew McConaughey's limited screen time in the film makes it not worth watching for die-hard fans

review: I have been looking for this film for ages because it is quite rare to find as it was one of the video nasties. I finally found it on DVD at the end of last year. It is a very low budget movie. The story is set around Amazon jungle tribes that are living in fear of the devil. Laura Crawford is a model who is kidnapped by a gang of thugs while she is working in South America. They take her into the jungle where Laura is guarded by a ridiculous native who calls himself 'The Devil.' She has to go through all unpleasant things until they are happy. Maidens are chained up. The devil demonstrates eating flesh in a horrible manner. Peter Weston is the devil hunter who goes into the jungle to try and rescue her.
agree: I agree with the review that this film is rare to find and has a low budget. The setting in the Amazon jungle and the theme of fear of the devil add an intriguing element to the story. The portrayal of the native as 'The Devil' and the rescue mission by Peter Weston create a sense of suspense and adventure.
disagree: I disagree with the review as the depiction of violence and exploitation of women in the film is disturbing and unacceptable. The use of such graphic and offensive scenes detracts from any potential entertainment value the movie may have had. The portrayal of indigenous tribes in a negative light perpetuates harmful stereotypes and should not be glorified in any way.

review: Not sure if I'm referring to those who labeled this a video nasty or to the director..."Devil Hunter" sure is one bizarre 'horror' movie. The plot is a loosey goosey combo of superior films like "Cannibal Ferox" and "Cut and Run." Chick gets kidnapped in the 'jungle' by a 'tribe' of 'savages.' The jungle looks more like a park somewhere in Mexico. The tribe is like a group of hippies who walk around in Party City-style Halloween costume renditions of tribal garb. And the savages range in race from white to Asian to black to hispanic. I suppose Franco just grabbed anyone who looked even slightly ethnic for this romp. To make matters worse, this film has ultra-minimal gore, no real scares and a lot of unnecessary penis. Not fun. I can find something to like in just about any sleazy Italian or Euro-trash film; this one just fell WAY short. 2 out of 10, kids.
agree: I completely agree with this review. "Devil Hunter" was indeed a bizarre horror movie that failed to deliver on the elements that make such films enjoyable. The lack of scares, minimal gore, and unnecessary focus on certain aspects detracted from the overall viewing experience. The disjointed plot and questionable casting choices only added to the disappointment.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While "Devil Hunter" may not have been a masterpiece, its eccentricities and unconventional approach to the horror genre could be seen as a refreshing change from more formulaic films. The diverse casting and unique setting may have been intentional choices by the director to create a different kind of viewing experience. Additionally, the film's departure from traditional horror tropes could be viewed as a bold artistic statement rather than a failure.

review: This video nasty was initially banned in Britain, and allowed in last November without cuts. It features the Playboy Playmate of the Month October 1979, Ursula Buchfellner. The opening cuts back and forth between Buchfellner and foggy jungle pictures. I am not sure what the purpose of that was. It would have been much better to focus on the bathtub scene. Laura (Buchfellner) is kidnapped and held in the jungle for ransom. Peter (Al Cliver - The Beyond, Zombie) is sent to find her and the ransom. Of course, one of the kidnappers (Antonio de Cabo) manages to pass the time productively, while another (Werner Pochath) whines incessantly. The ransom exchange goes to hell, and Laura runs into the jungle. Will Peter save her before the cannibals have a meal? Oh, yes, there are cannibals in this jungle. Why do you think it was a video nasty! Muriel Montossé is found by Peter and his partner (Antonio Mayans - Angel of Death) on the kidnapper's boat. Montossé is very comfortably undressed. Peter leaves them and goes off alone to find Laura, who has been captured by now. They pass the time having sex, and don't see the danger approaching. Guts, anyone? Great fight between Peter and the naked devil (Burt Altman). Blood, decapitation, guts, lots of full frontal, some great writhing by the cannibal priestess (Aline Mess), and the line, 'They tore her heart out,' which is hilarious if you see the film.
agree: I agree with the review that the film seems to have a disjointed focus, with unnecessary scenes that detract from the main storyline. The reviewer's point about the opening sequence and the bathtub scene resonates with me, as a more coherent narrative could have enhanced the viewing experience.
disagree: I disagree with the review's negative tone towards the film's graphic content and shock value. While the reviewer may find certain elements distasteful, it's important to acknowledge that such extreme themes are often characteristic of the horror genre and can be appreciated by fans for their boldness and boundary-pushing nature.

review: Of the three titles from Jess Franco to find their way onto the Official DPP Video Nasty list (Devil Hunter, Bloody Moon and Women Behind Bars) this is perhaps the least deserving of notoriety, being a dreadfully dull jungle clunker enlivened only very slightly by a little inept gore, a gratuitous rape scene, and loads of nudity. Gorgeous blonde Ursula Buchfellner plays movie star Laura Crawford who is abducted by a gang of ruthless kidnappers and taken to a remote tropical island inhabited by a savage tribe who worship the 'devil god' that lurks in the jungle (a big, naked, bulging-eyed native who likes to eat the hearts of nubile female sacrifices). Employed by Laura's agent to deliver a $6million ransom, brave mercenary Peter Weston (Al Cliver) and his Vietnam vet pilot pal travel to the island, but encounter trouble when the bad guys attempt a double-cross. During the confusion, Laura escapes into the jungle, but runs straight into the arms of the island's natives, who offer her up to their god. Franco directs in his usual torpid style and loads this laughable effort with his usual dreadful trademarks: crap gore, murky cinematography, rapid zooms, numerous crotch shots, out of focus imagery, awful sound effects, and ham-fisted editing. The result is a dire mess that is a real struggle to sit through from start to finish (It took me a couple of sittings to finish the thing), and even the sight of the luscious Buchfellner in all of her natural glory ain't enough to make me revisit this film in a hurry.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The film sounds like a tedious and poorly executed mess, with little to redeem it other than gratuitous elements like gore, nudity, and a rape scene. Jess Franco's trademark style seems to have only added to the overall disappointment, making it a challenging watch that lacks substance or quality.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have its flaws and may not be a masterpiece, it seems to offer a certain level of entertainment value with its mix of jungle adventure, suspense, and elements of horror. The presence of Ursula Buchfellner and the exotic setting could potentially provide some visual appeal and intrigue for viewers who enjoy exploitation cinema. Despite the criticisms of Franco's directing style, there

review: How can you tell that a horror movie is terrible? When you can't stop laughing about it of course! The plot has been well covered by other reviewers, so I'll just add a few things on the hilarity of it all. Some reviews have placed the location in South America, others in Africa, I thought it was in some random island in the Pacific. Where exactly does this take place, seems to be a mystery. The cannibal tribe is conformed by a couple of black women some black men, and a man who looks like a young Frank Zappa banging the drums... the Devil God is a large black man with a terrible case of pink eyes. One of the 'freakiest' moments in the film is when 'Pablito' find his partner hanging from a tree covered in what seems to be an orange substance that I assume is blood, starts screaming for minutes on and on (that's actually funny), and then the head of his partner falls in the ground and 'Pablito' kicks it a bit for what I assume is 'shits n' giggles' and the eyes actually move... But, of course, then the 'freak' is gone when you realize the eyes moved because the movie is just bad... I hadn't laughed like this in a loooong while, and I definitely recommend this film for a Sunday afternoon with your friends and you have nothing to do... grab a case of beers and start watching this film, you'll love it! If you are looking for a real horror or gore movie, though... don't' bother.
agree: I agree with the review that this horror movie is so bad that it becomes unintentionally funny. The absurdity of the plot and the bizarre characters make it a perfect choice for a lighthearted movie night with friends. The reviewer's description of the scenes and characters aligns with the idea that the movie's flaws actually enhance its entertainment value.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment that the hilarity of the movie makes it worth watching. While it's true that some horror movies can be so bad they're good, in this case, it seems like the film's shortcomings detract from any potential enjoyment. The lack of a coherent plot, inconsistent setting, and poorly executed 'freaky' moments suggest that the movie falls short of being entertaining, even in a campy way.

review: An actress making a movie in Africa is kidnapped and taken into the jungle where she is held for ransom. The producer hires someone to go and bring her back. Complicating everything are the cannibals in the jungle who worship a really ugly looking 'god' who likes to eat naked women. This is a gory sleazy movie with copious amounts of nudity and violence, designed to appeal to the darkest parts of our being. However, the film is ultimately a snoozer with off-kilter pacing and minimal dialogue.
agree: I completely agree with this review. While the movie may have elements that could appeal to certain audiences, the overall execution falls flat. The disjointed plot lines and lack of engaging dialogue make it difficult to stay invested in the film. The excessive gore and nudity do little to make up for the lackluster storytelling and pacing.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may not be everyone's cup of tea due to its graphic content, it serves its purpose as an exploitation film. The intentional shock value and disturbing imagery are characteristic of the genre, and for those who enjoy this type of cinema, it delivers on those fronts. The lack of dialogue and slow pacing could be seen as a deliberate choice to create a sense of unease and tension throughout the film.

review: For anyone who was praying for the sight of Al Cliver wrestling a naked, 7ft tall black guy into a full nelson, this film has arrived! It features a kidnapped film starlet, a rugged Vietnam vet hired to save her, and a local tribe with a monster cannibal god.
agree: I agree that the film's entertainment value is boosted by the hilarious dub track and the goofy monster with bulging eyes. The strong EuroCult supporting cast and the nudity and gore elements add to the overall experience. The slow fistfight between Cliver and Antonio de Cabo was a highlight for me as well.
disagree: I disagree with the criticism of the film's length. While it may have been padded out, the extra runtime allows for more development of the story and characters. Additionally, the technical issues mentioned, such as ghosting images and missing subtitles, can detract from the viewing experience and should have been addressed.

review: Devil Hunter gained notoriety for being on the DPP 'Video Nasty' list, but it really needn't have been. The plot gives the film a decent base, but it plods along without many scenes of interest. Jess Franco's talent is overshadowed by films like this.
agree: I completely agree with this review. Devil Hunter may have its place on the 'Video Nasty' list, but it falls short in delivering a compelling story or engaging scenes. Jess Franco's potential is wasted on this film, and it's disappointing to see his talent overshadowed by lackluster content.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While Devil Hunter may not be a standout film, it still offers a unique premise and some suspenseful moments. Jess Franco's direction, though not at its best here, still showcases his ability to create tension and intrigue. The film's inclusion on the 'Video Nasty' list adds to its cult appeal and makes it worth a watch for fans of the genre.

review: This film seemed way too long even at only 75 minutes. The problem with jungle horror films is that there is always way too much footage of people walking (through the jungle, up a rocky cliff, near a river or lake) to pad out the running time. The film is worth seeing for the laughable and naked native zombie with big bulging, bloody eyes which is always accompanied on the soundtrack with heavy breathing and lots of reverb. Eurotrash fans will be plenty entertained by the bad English dubbing, gratuitous female flesh and very silly makeup jobs on the monster and native extras. For a zombie/cannibal flick this was pretty light on the gore but then I probably didn't see an uncut version.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The pacing of the film was indeed slow due to excessive footage of people walking through the jungle, which made it feel longer than its actual runtime. The elements mentioned, such as the laughable native zombie and the Eurotrash aesthetics, were the highlights that kept the film somewhat entertaining despite its flaws.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment of the film's length. While there may have been scenes of people walking through the jungle to fill time, the overall pacing and runtime did not feel excessively long to me. Additionally, the focus on the campy elements like bad dubbing and makeup added to the charm of the movie, making it an enjoyable watch for fans of the genre.

review: Not only is it a disgustingly made low-budget bad-acted movie, but the plot itself is just STUPID!!! A mystic man that eats women? (And by the looks, not virgin ones) Ridiculous!!! If you´ve got nothing better to do (like sleeping) you should watch this. Yeah right.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie sounds like a complete disaster with a ridiculous plot and poor production quality. It's definitely not worth anyone's time.
disagree: I disagree with this review. While the premise may sound strange, sometimes unconventional plots can be intriguing and entertaining. Low-budget films can also surprise viewers with their creativity and unique storytelling. It might be worth giving it a chance for those looking for something different.

review: This is the worst thing the TMNT franchise has ever spawned. I was a kid when this came out and I still thought it was deuce, even though I liked the original cartoon. There's this one scene I remember when the mafia ape guy explains to his minions what rhetorical questions are. It's atrocious. Many fans hate on the series for including a female turtle, but that didn't bother me. So much so that I didn't even remember her until I read about the show recently. All in all, it's miserably forgettable. The only okay thing was the theme song. Guilty pleasure, they call it... Nananana ninja...
agree: I completely agree with this review. The TMNT series mentioned sounds like a disappointing addition to the franchise, especially with the lackluster scenes and forgettable characters. It's a shame when a beloved franchise produces something that falls so short of expectations.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the reviewer found the series to be the worst in the TMNT franchise, I believe that every iteration of a beloved series can have its own unique appeal. The inclusion of a female turtle could have been a refreshing change and the theme song being a guilty pleasure shows that there are still some redeeming qualities to be found.

review: This is the biggest insult to TMNT ever. Fortunantely, officially Venus does not exist in canon TMNT. There will never be a female turtle, this took away from the tragic tale of 4 male unique mutants who will never have a family of their own, once gone no more. The biggest mistake was crossing over Power Rangers to TMNT with a horrible episode; the turtle's voices were WRONG and they all acted out of character. They could have done such a better job, better designs and animatronics and NO VENUS. don't bother with this people...it's cringe worthy material. the lip flap was slow and unnatural looking. they totally disrespected shredder. the main baddie, some dragonlord dude was corny. the turtles looked corny with things hanging off their bodies, what's with the thing around raph's thigh? the silly looking sculpted plastrons!? If they looked normal, acted in character and got rid of Venus, got rid of the stupid kiddie cartoon sounds...and better writing it could have been good.
agree: I agree with the review that the addition of Venus as a female turtle was a departure from the original TMNT concept and took away from the unique dynamic of the four male turtles. The crossover with Power Rangers felt forced and the characters did not stay true to their established personalities. The design choices and animatronics could have been better executed, and the overall execution of the show was disappointing.
disagree: I disagree with the review's harsh criticism of the show's visuals and character designs. While the addition of Venus may have deviated from the traditional TMNT storyline, it could have provided an interesting new perspective. The crossover with Power Rangers could have been a fun and exciting concept if executed well. The show's unique style and creative choices may not have appealed to everyone, but they added a fresh take on the classic TMNT universe.

review: I did not like the idea of the female turtle at all since 1987 we knew the TMNT to be four brothers with their teacher Splinter and their enemies and each one of the four brothers are named after the great artists name like Leonardo, Michelangelo, Raphael, and Donatello so Venus here doesn't have any meaning or playing any important part. I believe that the old TMNT series was much better than the new one which contains Venus. As a female turtle, she will not add any action to the story. We like the story of the TMNT we knew in 1987 to have new enemies in every part is a good point to have some action but to have a female turtle is a very weak point to have some action. We wish to see more new of TMNT series but just as the same characters we knew in 1987 without that female turtle.
agree: I agree with the reviewer that introducing a female turtle, Venus, into the TMNT series deviates from the original concept of the four brothers named after great artists. The addition of Venus does not seem to add significant value or enhance the action in the story. The original TMNT series with the four brothers and their teacher Splinter was a classic that resonated with fans, and the introduction of a new character like Venus may not be well-received by those who appreciate the traditional dynamics of the group.
disagree: I disagree with the reviewer's stance on the introduction of Venus as a female turtle in the TMNT series. While the original concept of the four brothers named after artists is iconic, introducing a female character like Venus can bring diversity and new perspectives to the story. Adding a female turtle could provide an opportunity to explore different dynamics within the group and offer fresh storytelling possibilities. It's important for franchises to evolve and introduce new elements to keep the narrative engaging and relevant for audiences.

review: This film is terrible. You don't really need to read this review further. If you are planning on watching it, suffice to say - don't (unless you are studying how not to make a good movie). The acting is horrendous... serious amateur hour. Throughout the movie I thought that it was interesting that they found someone who speaks and looks like Michael Madsen, only to find out that it is actually him! A new low even for him!! The plot is terrible. People who claim that it is original or good have probably never seen a decent movie before. Even by the standard of Hollywood action flicks, this is a terrible movie. Don't watch it!!! Go for a jog instead - at least you won't feel like killing yourself.

review: Terrible movie. Nuff Said. These Lines are Just Filler. The movie was bad. Why I have to expand on that I don't know. This is already a waste of my time. I just wanted to warn others. review: Assuming this won't end up a straight-to-video release, I would have to say void this title at all costs. Unless you're bored of good, well-executed movies, that is. I saw this last night at AFI Dallas, and I left with 20 minutes remaining, simply because I didn't care anymore (about the plot, not about insulting the director...that is awkward). When you can spot a goof only 5 minutes into the movie (a shot out, shattered window before any shots are fired...and then the window breaks with the first shot), things are going to bad. Let's just say this is only an indicator of things to come...unfortunately. I'll spare you all the details, but this is sub-par in every manner, even the half-assed acting by Michael Madsen is disappointing when you're expecting half-assed acting from him. And the rape scene...Christ! "Shut up and take it" should never be used in a rape scene. EVER. 3/10

review: Sometimes a movie is so comprehensively awful it has a destructive effect on your morale. You begin to really ask yourself, what does it mean for our society that the standard is so terribly low? Can they honestly expect that we'll endure this many clichés and still be entertained? Of course, it is still a Hollywood mainstay to make the GUN the major character, plot device, and the source of all conflict and resolution in films. Character needs a gun. Gets a gun. Can't do that because he has a gun. Puts his gun down first. OH MY GOD What are we going to do!? He has a gun! He waves it around, acting more malicious than real human beings ever do. He pushes it in someone's face for 90 minutes, shouting questions. The hallmark of any conclusion will be the comforting sound of police sirens. It's a real challenge to make such a tired, hackneyed formula work again; a film has to be very clever and well executed. This one is neither. It has no life and no personality, and it will suck these components from YOU. it will make you feel WORSE about living in the time and space that you do. Really, who needs that!? So yes, I'll say it: I think this may well be the worst film I have ever seen. Anyone who was involved in the making of this sub- mediocre soul killing trash should be publicly embarrassed for the disservice they've done to us all.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The portrayal of guns as the central focus in movies has become a tired and overused trope in Hollywood. The lack of originality and reliance on clichés in this film only serves to further diminish the quality of storytelling in cinema. It's disheartening to see such uninspired content being produced and presented to audiences.
disagree: While I understand the frustration with the overuse of clichés and reliance on guns as a plot device in movies, I believe that there are still ways for films to explore these themes in a fresh and engaging manner. Not all movies that feature guns as a central element are inherently bad; it ultimately comes down to the execution and creativity of the filmmakers. While this particular film may have failed to deliver on those fronts, I don't think it's fair to categorically dismiss all movies that involve guns in their narratives.

review: I have to congratulate the genius who approved this one. Edward Furlong, you're not as good as you think mate, you can't grab on every piece of low-cost amateur crap, which sole intention has to be to get some bucks. The filming is bad, and I mean BAD. Anyone with a camera would get the same result, or better. The acting, lets just say: don't go to the supermarket looking for actors. The good ones usually come with a degree or, at least, have some damn experience! The director.. Mr. Jon Keeyes, please find your purpose in life, as a director you simply suck. Your directing is poor, the angles are all messed up (not in a good way), the lines seem as if they're being read out of toilet paper, and the damn music.. it always comes up when it shouldn't and goes out for no apparent reason. And don't go for writer either, by the way. Making movies isn't like serving on a coffeeshop, it requires art and skill, things I really doubt you'll ever have. Instead of making a badass shootout movie, you should've shot this one back to oblivion and wait 'till something good came up.. Or just go find a job on a coffeeshop. You'll have less stress and you'll save movie goers some money and a bad night. vote: 1/10 (my first one)

review: I rented this one on DVD without any prior knowledge. I was suspicious seeing Michael Madsen appearing in a movie I have never heard of, but it was a freebie, so why not check it out. Well my guess is that Mr. Blonde would very much like to forget he's ever taken part in such a shame of a film. Apparently, if your script and dialogs are terrible, even good actors cannot save the day. Not to mention the amateur actors that flood this film. Too many non-native-English-speakers play parts of native-English-speakers, reading out lines from a script that should have been thrown away and not having been made into a movie. It's unbelievable how unbelievable all the lines in the movie sound. The music is awful and totally out of place, and the whole thing looks and sounds like a poor school play. I recommend you watch it just so you would appreciate other, better, movies. This is why I gave it a 3 instead of the 1 it deserves.

review: I saw this DVD in my friend's house and thought that this was a Turkish action movie with some Hollywood-not very big-names in it. Interested enough I decide to give it a shot later. It was a tough to bear experience believe me. Then, after finally seeing the credits roll I thought 'We Turks really suck at Hollywood style film making.. This is an insult to the heist|hostage movie genre..' but then wait! I checked some names and no, they were not Turkish names and no, this was not a Turkish movie; on the contrary it was literally shot in America with an American director & crew! That made me thinking-again!- How on earth can you persuade names like Micheal Madsen, Edward Furlong or even Arnold Vosloo to take part in such a project? with money probably.. That kept me thinking further.. How can you raise such amount of money to offer them and a supposedly international cast? Then all my meditation paid off and I came to find the answer. By hiring the cheapest equipment and crew that you can find. And if you still have difficulty in adjusting your budget then: by writing and directing the movie you are trying to produce-or vice versa I don't have any information on that-. So bottom line this is not a bad movie as everybody is so anxious to present as.. It makes you think -in my case even meditate- and there are a lot of movies out there that don't give even that effect.. This one at least makes you think; It makes you wonder.. It leaves you with disbelief.. and then It makes you wonder again..
agree: I agree with the reviewer that this movie was a challenging experience to watch and that it may not have lived up to expectations in terms of Hollywood-style filmmaking. The points raised about the budget constraints and the potential impact on the overall production quality are valid. It's commendable that the reviewer found value in the film's ability to provoke thought and reflection, even if the execution may have fallen short in certain aspects.
