The fact that the reviewer found the experience tough to bear and questioned the involvement of well

review: What was with all the Turkish actors? No offense but I thought it was all for nothing for all these actors. The film had no script to test any actors acting skill or ability. It demanded next to nothing I bought this film to see Michael Madsen. He is one of my favorite actors but this film was another failure for him. The script was so bad. Their was just nothing to sink your teeth into and all the characters were two dimensional. Madsen tried to act like a hard ass but the script and direction didn't even allow him to do enough with his character to make it more interesting or 3 dimensional. Even the sound effects of the gunfight at the beginning of the film sounded like the noise of paint ball guns when they are fired in a skirmish. It was really weird and they didn't sound like real guns. A video game had better sound effects than this film. There was also a really annoying bloke at the beginning of the film who was a member of the robbery gang. He had this American whining voice like a girl shouting lines like 'Lets get the F#$k out of here' and 'What are we going to do man'. He sounded like a girl. As a positive It was funny to watch and it made me laugh too. For a few seconds. Whoo Hoo ! Dumb Film. Poor Madsen. He will bounce back...

review: This movie was terrible. at first i just read the plot summary and it looked OK, so i watched it. I've watched it at least 20 times.... the plot was also crap. the writers were probably sleep deprived when they came up with the lines. on the plus side, it's the good kind of bad movie. the one you keep watching just to see how much worst could it will get, so that later you can tell other people how you couldn't believe how terrible the movie was. i think everybody should watch this, so that then we could appreciate better other, REAL, movies.

review: I am a big fan of Arnold Vosloo. Finally seeing him as the star of a recent movie, not just a bit part, made me happy. Unfortunately I took film appreciation in college and the only thing I can say that I didn't like was that the film was made in an abandoned part of town and there was no background traffic or lookie loos. I have to say that the acting leaves something to be desired, but Arnold is an excellent actor, I have to chalk it up to lousy direction and the supporting cast leaves something to be desired. I love Arnold Vosloo, and he made the film viewable. Otherwise, I would have written it off as another lousy film. I found the rape scene brutal and unnecessary, but the actors that got away at the end were pretty good. But the sound effects of the shoot-out were pretty bad. There are some glitches in the film (continuity) but they are overlookable considering the low-caliber of the film. All in all I enjoyed the film, because Arnold Vosloo was in it.

review: This is an art film that was either made in 1969 or 1972 (the National Film Preservation Foundation says 1969 and IMDb says 1972). Regardless of the exact date, the film definitely appears to be very indicative of this general time period--with some camera-work and pop art stylings that are pure late 60s-early 70s. The film consists of three simple images that are distorted using different weird camera tricks. These distorted images are accompanied by music and there is absolutely no dialog or plot of any sort. This was obviously intended as almost like a form of performance art, and like most performance art, it's interesting at first but quickly becomes tiresome. The film, to put it even more bluntly, is a total bore and would appeal to no one but perhaps those who made the film, their family and friends and perhaps a few people just too hip and 'with it' to be understood by us mortals.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The film's experimental nature and lack of plot or dialogue may appeal to a niche audience, but for the average viewer, it can quickly become tedious and unengaging. The dated camera tricks and pop art stylings may be interesting from a historical perspective, but they do little to elevate the overall viewing experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the film may not be everyone's cup of tea, its avant-garde approach and lack of traditional narrative can be seen as a bold artistic statement. The experimental nature of the film, coupled with its unique visuals and music, may actually appeal to viewers looking for something outside the mainstream. It's important to appreciate art films for their unconventional qualities and the different perspectives they offer.

review: Nine minutes of psychedelic, pulsating, often symmetric abstract images, are enough to drive anyone crazy. I did spot a full-frame eye at the start, and later some birds silhouetted against other colors. It was just not my cup of tea. It's about 8½ minutes too long.

review: There are times when finishing a film one wishes to have a refund for the time just spent. This was one of those times. I almost gave up with only 15 minutes left to endure... and I wish I had... The pace that a man goes from a straight-laced, controlled life to one of complete spinelessness and irresponsibility could never be this rapid. From a graduation celebration to the predictable ending Tristan Price (Jesse Metcalfe) man of privilege and culture allows himself to be seduced by a woman, by violence, and by mind altering substances. Of course, the woman part is understandable when observing the talents of the beautiful April (Nathalie Kelley). But the in for a penny in for a pound aspect of the drugs, violence and dedication to a person he has just met is impossible to understand. Frankly, besides being able to stare at Nathalie Kelley and Monica Keena, this film has no redeeming qualities. Save your money, save your time... do anything else...
agree: I completely agree with this review. The rapid transformation of the main character and the lack of believability in his actions made the film difficult to watch. The performances of the actresses may have been a highlight, but overall, the film lacked substance and failed to engage the audience.
disagree: I disagree with this review. While the pacing may have been off and the character development unrealistic, the film still had some redeeming qualities. The performances of Nathalie Kelley and Monica Keena were captivating, and the exploration of privilege and culture could have been interesting if executed better. Despite its flaws, the film may still have some value for viewers looking for a visually appealing experience.

review: Weak plot, predictable violence, only semi interesting characters. Like the writer (also one of the stars?) was fictionalizing his own screw ups and added an incredulous fantasies of drugs and murder to make it 'hot'. From the predictable rap and house soundtrack, to the family conflicts, it's poorly acted, stereotypical, and ultimately terribly boring. Even the title has been done before - IMDb lists FIVE movies with the same name released in 2007-2008!! Note: Saw it on Showtime, which listed the synopsis for one of the other movies. Was halfway thru before I realized no one was an undercover cop. Even tho another stereotype, would have made it interesting if it happened.

The attempt to add elements of drugs and murder felt forced and unoriginal. The film's soundtrack and family conflicts were cliché, and the overall execution was disappointing. The title being unoriginal further added to the lackluster experience. The potential twist of having an undercover cop could have added some intrigue to the story.

The title similarity to other movies may not have been a major issue, as each film can bring a unique perspective. Overall, I found the movie to be entertaining and worth watching.

review: This film had a lot of promise, and the plot was relatively interesting, however the actors, director and editors seriously let this film down. I feel bad for the writers, it could have been good. The acting is wooden, very few of the characters are believable. Who ever edited this clearly just learnt some new edit techniques and wanted to splash them all over the film. There are lots of quick 'flashy' edits in almost every scene, which are clearly meant to be symbolic but just end up as annoying. I wanted to like this film and expected there to be a decent resolution to the breakdown of equilibrium but alas no, it left me feeling like I'd wasted my time and the film makers had wasted their money.

I honestly cant understand how this type of nonsense gets produced and actually released, does somebody somewhere not at some stage think, 'Oh my god this really is a load of shite' and call it a day. Its crap like this that has people downloading illegally, the trailer looks like a completely different film, at least if you have download it, you haven't wasted your time or money Don't waste your time, this is painful.

review: This is really a new low in entertainment. Even though there are a lot worse movies out. In the Gangster / Drug scene genre it is hard to have a convincing storyline (this movies does not, i mean Sebastians motives for example couldn't be more far fetched and worn out cliché.) Then you would also need a setting of character relationships that is believable (this movie does not.) Sure Tristan is drawn away from his family but why was that again? what's the deal with his father again that he has to ask permission to go out at his age? interesting picture though to ask about the lack and need of rebellious behavior of kids in upper class family. But this movie does not go in this direction. Even though there would be the potential judging by the random Backflashes. Wasn't he already down and out, why does he do it again? So there are some interesting questions brought up here for a solid socially critic drama (but then again, this movie is just not, because of focusing on "cool" production techniques and special effects an not giving the characters a moment to reflect and most of all forcing the story along the path where they want it to be and not paying attention to let the story breath and naturally evolve.) It wants to be a drama to not glorify abuse of substances and violence (would be political incorrect these days, wouldn't it?) but on the other hand it is nothing more then a cheap action movie (like there are so so many out there) with an average set of actors and a Vinnie Jones who is managing to not totally ruin what's left of his reputation by doing what he always does. So all in all i .. just ... can't recommend it. 1 for Vinnie and 2 for the editing.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie fails to deliver a convincing storyline and believable character relationships in the Gangster/Drug scene genre. The motives of the characters feel cliché and far-fetched, and the film lacks depth in exploring the dynamics between the characters. The focus on 'cool' production techniques and special effects detracts from allowing the story to naturally evolve and the characters to reflect. It falls short of being a solid socially critical drama and instead veers towards being a cheap action movie with average performances.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may not excel in delivering a compelling storyline and believable

review: From the beginning of the movie, it gives the feeling the director is trying to portray something, what I mean to say that instead of the story dictating the style in which the movie should be made, he has gone in the opposite way, he had a type of move that he wanted to make, and wrote a story to suite it. While the plot may have had some redeeming qualities, the overall experience was lacking and not worth the time unless you are a die-hard fan of a specific cast member.
disagree: I disagree with the review's focus on CHACE CRAWFORD as the main reason for watching the movie. While his presence may have been a draw for some viewers, it should not overshadow the overall quality of the film. The reviewer's emphasis on the cast's physical appearance detracts from a more critical analysis of the movie's storytelling and filmmaking techniques.

review: This fanciful horror flick has Vincent Price playing a mad magician that realizes his vocational talents have been sold to another. He devise ways of avenging all those that have wronged him. His master scheme seems to back fire on him. Price is a little below par compared to his masterpieces, but is still the only reason to watch this thriller. Supporting cast includes Patrick O'Neal, Mary Murphy, Eva Gabor and Jay Novello.
agree: I agree with this review. Vincent Price's performance is indeed the highlight of the movie, and while the plot may be a bit lacking, his presence alone makes it worth watching.
disagree: I disagree with this review. While Vincent Price's performance may be a standout, the supporting cast also delivers strong performances that add depth to the film. The storyline, though fanciful, is engaging and keeps the audience on the edge of their seats throughout.

review: If I had not read Pat Barker's 'Union Street' before seeing this film, I would have liked it. Unfortunately this is not the case. It is actually my kind of film, it is well made, and in no way do I want to say otherwise, but as an adaptation, it fails from every angle.
agree: I completely agree with this review. Having read the novel 'Union Street' before watching the film, I also found the adaptation lacking in capturing the raw and gritty essence of the original work. While the film was well-made and had positive elements, it failed to truly convey the darkness and harsh realities depicted in the book.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I understand the disappointment in the film not fully capturing the essence of the novel 'Union Street', I believe that adaptations often have to make creative choices to fit the medium of film. The movie may have taken a different approach, but it still managed to convey important themes and emotions, making it a compelling watch in its own right.

review: I saw the capsule comment said 'great acting.' In my opinion, these are two great actors giving horrible performances, and with zero chemistry with one another, for a great director in his all-time worst effort. Robert De Niro has to be the most ingenious and insightful illiterate of all time. Jane Fonda's performance uncomfortably drifts all over the map as she clearly has no handle on this character, mostly because the character is so poorly written. Molasses-like would be too swift an adjective for this film's excruciating pacing. Although the film's intent is to be an uplifting story of curing illiteracy, watching it is a true 'bummer.' I give it 1 out of 10, truly one of the worst 20 movies for its budget level that I have ever seen.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The performances by the lead actors were indeed lackluster and lacked chemistry. The pacing of the film was excruciatingly slow, making it difficult to stay engaged. The characters seemed poorly written, and the overall execution of the film fell short of expectations. I also found it to be a disappointing effort from a usually great director.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the performances may not have been the best from these talented actors, I believe they still brought depth to their characters. The film's message about illiteracy and the journey to overcome it can be seen as uplifting and important. Additionally, the director's vision, even if not executed perfectly, still had merit. Overall, I found some redeeming qualities in the film despite its flaws.

review: Robert DeNiro plays the most unbelievably intelligent illiterate of all time. This movie is so wasteful of talent, it is truly disgusting. The script is unbelievable. The dialog is unbelievable. Jane Fonda's character is a caricature of herself, and not a funny one. The movie moves at a snail's pace, is photographed in an ill-advised manner, and is insufferably preachy. It also plugs in every cliche in the book. Swoozie Kurtz is excellent in a supporting role, but so what? Equally annoying is this new IMDB rule of requiring ten lines for every review. When a movie is this worthless, it doesn't require ten lines of text to let other readers know that it is a waste of time and tape. Avoid this movie.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The portrayal of an intelligent illiterate by Robert DeNiro was indeed unbelievable and a waste of his talent. The script and dialogues were poorly executed, and Jane Fonda's character felt like a caricature. The pacing of the movie was slow, the cinematography was lacking, and the overall preachiness was off-putting. Swoozie Kurtz's performance may have been a highlight, but it couldn't salvage the film's shortcomings. This movie is definitely one to avoid.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While I acknowledge the criticisms regarding the portrayal of the characters and the pacing of the movie, I believe that the talented cast, including Robert DeNiro and Jane Fonda, brought depth to their roles. The film may have used cliches, but it also offered a unique perspective on the themes it explored. Swoozie Kurtz's performance added value to the supporting cast, enhancing the overall viewing experience. Despite its flaws, this movie may still have some redeeming qualities worth considering.

review: Story of a man who has unnatural feelings for a pig. Starts out with a opening scene that is a terrific example of absurd comedy. A formal orchestra audience is turned into an insane, violent mob by the crazy chantings of it's singers. Unfortunately it stays absurd the WHOLE time with no general narrative eventually making it just too off putting. Even those from the era should be turned off. The cryptic dialogue would make Shakespeare seem easy to a third grader. On a technical level it's better than you might think with some good cinematography by future great Vilmos Zsigmond. Future stars Sally Kirkland and Frederic Forrest can be seen briefly.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The absurdity of the film was overwhelming and the lack of a coherent narrative made it difficult to engage with the story. The cryptic dialogue was indeed challenging to follow, and while the technical aspects were commendable, they couldn't make up for the overall off-putting nature of the film.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have been absurd and challenging in its narrative, I found it to be a bold and unique piece of cinema. The unconventional approach and cryptic dialogue added to its artistic value, and the technical aspects, especially the cinematography, were impressive. The film may not be for everyone, but it certainly has its merits.

review: Are my words harsh? I don't think so. When you watch any movie you want to see some creativity, some edible characters, and themes that seem to hit close to home. Bait contained none of these. While I will give Fuqua some credit for two of the scenes in this film, the remaining five hundred were disastrous.
agree: I completely agree with the review. The lack of creativity, unmanaged actors, and overall disappointment in Bait make it a difficult film to watch. The criticism of Jamie Foxx's performance and the lack of emotional depth in the movie are valid points that I also found to be major drawbacks.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment of Fuqua's potential and the emergence of his style in Bait. While the reviewer acknowledges some impressive scenes, I believe that the film as a whole failed to showcase Fuqua's true talent. The reliance on cliched action movie tropes and lackluster character development overshadow any glimpses of brilliance in the direction.

review: Ah, Bait. How do I hate thee? Let me count the ways. 1. You try to be funny, but are corny and unenjoyable; every joke is predictable and expected, and when it comes, does not inspire laughter. Instead, I want to hurl. 2. You try to be dramatic, but are unbelievable; the woman overacts to a terrible degree, and the 'bad guy' looks like Bill Gates, and is about as scary as...well, Bill Gates. (Just try to imagine Bill Gates trying to intimidate somebody with a gun. Doesn't work, does it? A lawyer, maybe, but not a gun. Doesn't fit.) As for Jamie Foxx, well, just watching him try to deliver a dramatic and heartfelt dialogue is ludicrous, and makes me want to hurl. 3. You try to be action-packed, but instead are dull and dragging too many times. And when the action heats up, the tripod for the camera must have been lost, for the scenes wobble more than those in The Blair Witch Project, and I find myself nauseated, and once again I want to hurl. 4. You try to be a good movie, but you failed, you FAILED, YOU FAILED! I would rather walk barefoot across the Sahara with a pack full of beef jerky and no water, no sunscreen, and only Meryl Streep for company. This hell would be lovelier than a single minute more spent watching everyone in Bait overact their way through an idiotically written story with Bill Gates for a bad guy, and let's not even talk about the massive bomb that goes off in a car that Jamie Foxx's character has just driven OFF A CLIFF, but somehow manages to escape...just kill me now, or do the right thing and promise me that somehow I'll never have to watch a movie that is this bad, ever again.
agree: I completely agree with this review. 'Bait' sounds like a disaster of a movie with overacting, predictable jokes, and unbelievable scenes. The reviewer's frustration is palpable, and I can understand why they would want to avoid such a film at all costs.
disagree: I have to disagree with this review. While 'Bait' may have its flaws, it could still offer some entertainment value to certain viewers. Sometimes a movie's campiness or

review: The movie seems to get a free pass because it is a Takashi film and nothing Takashi does can be wrong. This is a highschoolers approach to cinema. For the rest of us we'll find and hour and a half of a kid screaming for no real reason completely annoying (and yes, this does take away from the film), the pace of the film almost reaching levels of rigomortis, and the acting...well...hmmm.
agree: I completely agree with the review. While I am also a fan of Takashi Miike, I found this particular film lacking in many aspects. The overemphasis on the director's reputation rather than the actual quality of the movie is a valid point, and the issues with pacing and character development were evident throughout.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I understand the criticisms raised, I believe that Takashi Miike's unique style and approach to storytelling can be appreciated in this film. The unconventional narrative and visual elements may not appeal to everyone, but they contribute to the overall artistic vision of the movie. Additionally, the exploration of conflict and character depth, albeit subtle, adds layers to the viewing experience.

review: Uninspired direction leaves a decent cast stranded in a handsome but bland adaptation, in which dialogue seems recited rather than heartfelt, and cash strapped appearances by the ghosts fail to round up any sense of awe or magic; Edward Woodward, as the Ghost of Christmas Present, wobbles around on stilts and seems to be doing an impression of Bernard Cribbins. As Scrooge, George C. Scott is too wry, and he never seems to truly believe in it, which robs his performance of its effect. The scenes in which he's shown his past have as much impact as if he was half-heartedly flicking through his family album. No one else seems to be putting any effort in, except Frank Finlay, who chronically overacts.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The direction in this adaptation was indeed uninspired, and the performances lacked the depth and sincerity needed to bring the story to life. The portrayal of the ghosts was underwhelming, and the overall execution fell flat.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the direction may have been lacking, I found George C. Scott's portrayal of Scrooge to be compelling and nuanced. His performance added a layer of complexity to the character, and I believe he brought a fresh perspective to the role. Additionally, I appreciated Frank Finlay's over-the-top acting as it added a sense of theatricality to the film.

review: I was sooooo excited to see this movie after finally reading the book this week. My 13 year old son was looking forward to it too. I rented it and snuggled down to enjoy a classic holiday story brought to life on screen. Boy, was I disappointed. This movie veered off from the book more times than is forgivable. George C. Scott is an excellent actor but in this, it seemed that he was fully into character only about 20% of the time. The rest of the time he was quite flat. I realize that this was made in '84, pre-CG effects, for the most part. But it looked to be very B-movie quality, especially the encounter with Jacob Marley. The biggest disappointment was the fact that they left out one of the most moving parts of the story: When the Spirit of Christmas Present takes Scrooge on the whirlwind tour of the world, observing people in the bleakest of circumstances still having the light and love of Christmastime. I will admit that Mr. Scott did a good job with the 'reformed' Scrooge at the end. That was a refreshing portrayal. I wish that Bob Cratchit had been portrayed as a little more ragged and down-trodden. And Tiny Tim... oh don't even get me started on bad child actors...
agree: I completely understand your disappointment with the movie adaptation. It's always frustrating when a beloved book is not faithfully translated to the screen. The deviations from the original story and the lackluster performances can really detract from the viewing experience. I agree that George C. Scott's portrayal seemed inconsistent, and the overall quality of the production may not have lived up to expectations. It's a shame that such a poignant moment like the whirlwind tour was omitted, as it holds significant emotional weight in the narrative. Your points about the portrayal of Bob Cratchit and Tiny Tim are valid, as they are crucial characters in the story. It's disappointing when key elements are not given the attention they deserve in a film adaptation.
disagree: While I understand your disappointment with the movie adaptation deviating from the book, I actually found George C. Scott's performance to be quite compelling. I thought he brought a unique depth to the character of Scrooge, especially in the reformed scenes towards the end. Additionally, I appreciated the effort to portray a different

review: Having seen three other versions of the same film, I am afraid for me this is by far the weakest, primarily due to Scott's rather dull and leaden performance. His emotions throughout are so bland it makes it difficult to engage in the film. Alistair Sim portrayed the role infinitely better. When Scrooge was at his meanest, you don't get the sense Scott is saying the dialogue with much conviction and when he undergoes his metamorphosis he is similarly unconvincing. I cannot think of any actors in this film who match those from the Alistair Sim version. Even the musical version (and frankly the Muppets) take on this are better executed. Very disappointing.
agree: I completely agree with this review. Scott's performance was indeed lackluster and failed to convey the emotional depth required for the role of Scrooge. Alistair Sim's portrayal remains unmatched, and other versions of the film, such as the musical and Muppets adaptations, were more engaging and better executed.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While Scott's performance may not have been as strong as Alistair Sim's, I believe he brought his own interpretation to the role of Scrooge. His portrayal may have been different, but it still had its merits and added a unique perspective to the story. Additionally, the film as a whole may have had its flaws, but it still offered a fresh take on a classic tale.

review: Saw this movie in my English class this afternoon and was surprised by how bad this version was. Don't get me wrong, George C. Scott was terrific as Scrooge, but the rest of the cast fails so very badly. Sometimes I couldn't stop laughing at the stupid acting and the repeated line: "Merry Christmas to everyone!" Other times I almost fell asleep. The movie is based on a Charles Dickens short story about a rich guy, who don't think Christmas is nothing but humbug. After 30 minutes, the rich guy is visited by three ghosts, who persuade him to celebrate Christmas after all. I can not understand how this movie, with a script so bad it must have been written in five minutes, can be so well-rated. Instead of this piece of garbage, I recommend to you, the Bill Murray comedy Scrooged. That at least, was funny.
agree: I completely agree with this review. While George C. Scott's performance as Scrooge was commendable, the overall quality of the movie suffered greatly due to the poor acting of the rest of the cast and the lackluster script. I found myself cringing at times and struggling to stay engaged with the story. The comparison to the comedy Scrooged is valid, as it offers a more entertaining and engaging take on the classic tale.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While I acknowledge that the movie may have had its flaws, I believe that George C. Scott's portrayal of Scrooge was truly exceptional and carried the film. The themes of redemption and the Christmas spirit were effectively conveyed through his performance, making the movie worth watching despite some shortcomings in other areas. Additionally, the classic story by Charles Dickens itself holds timeless value and should be appreciated for its enduring message.

review: When will the hurting stop? I never want to see another version of a Christmas Carol again. They keep on making movies with the same story, falling over each other in trying to make the movie better than the rest, but sadly fail to do so, as this is not a good story. Moralistic, old-fashioned, conservative happy-thinking. As if people learn. The numerous different versions of this film prove that we don´t.
agree: I completely understand your frustration with the constant remakes of A Christmas Carol. It can feel repetitive and uninspired when the same story is retold repeatedly without bringing anything new to the table. The moralistic and conservative themes may not resonate with everyone, and it's disappointing when filmmakers fail to offer a fresh perspective on such a well-known tale.
disagree: While I respect your opinion, I have to disagree with your assessment of A Christmas Carol. The timeless story of redemption and the spirit of Christmas is a classic for a reason. Each adaptation brings its own unique interpretation and can resonate with audiences in different ways. The themes of compassion and personal growth are universal and continue to be relevant today, making this story enduring and impactful.

review: I find that Father of the Pride is a complete rip-off of The Simpsons, only replacing yellow human characters with lions. It didn't impress me much and I've seen better from The Simpsons.
agree: I completely agree with this review. Father of the Pride does feel like a lesser version of The Simpsons, lacking the same level of humor and originality. The comparison to The Simpsons highlights the shortcomings of Father of the Pride.
disagree: I disagree with the review to some extent. While Father of the Pride may not be as strong as The Simpsons, I believe it still has its own charm and moments of humor. The show may not be groundbreaking, but it can still offer some entertainment value.

review: This is blatantly a futuristic adaptation of Jules Verne's 'Mysterious Island'. The sound editing is pretty bad. You hear the dialogue on set and you hear the voices being recorded on a recording booth at the same time! This is an amateur film with actors from Boston and shot around New Hampshire. For those living in New England and who are reading this comment will be wowed with a capital W. This film is full of flaws. You get to hear the director's voice giving directions and giving out directions to the actress. 'OK now stand up.' As for the other characters, there is this guy who talks with his mind instead of his voice and this blue alien. The alien guy talks with a deep voice. When he is yawning or grunting when he is fighting you hear the actor's voice. As for the special effects, man! This was Brett Piper's early work for crying out loud! The creatures are good but the animation is jerky. Really jerky. Sort of like Karl Zeman animation in 'Journey to the Beginning of Time' (1955). The special effects are imaginative. The music is good. Bottom line, this film makes 'Equinox' or 'Planet of the Dinosaurs' look like a Ray Harryhausen epic. Did you know 'Mysterious Planet' was a home movie and was on a shoestring budget? A must-watch for aspiring filmmakers.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The flaws in sound editing, amateurish acting, and visible directorial presence all detract from the overall viewing experience. While the special effects may be imaginative, the jerky animation and overall low-budget feel make it hard to fully appreciate the film's potential. This movie may have some charm for those familiar with the New England setting, but for most viewers, it falls short of expectations.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the film may have its flaws, such as sound editing issues and amateurish acting, it also offers a unique and imaginative take on the source material. The presence of the director's voice and the unconventional character traits add a layer of authenticity and creativity to the storytelling. Additionally, the special effects, despite their limitations, showcase the filmmaker's early work and potential. Overall, 'Mysterious Planet' may not be a polished production, but it has its own charm and could serve as inspiration for aspiring filmmakers.

review: Beyond a shadow of a doubt Mysterious Planet is one of the worst movies ever made, yet retains an affection in my heart because the poverty of its special effects and astoundingly awful sound track in the first 15 minutes (and to be honest that's all you need to see) combine to create something that is hilariously side-splitting. The opening scene in 'space' is just about as unfathomable as cinematography gets, as washing-up liquid bottles whiz past your eyes to muffled dialogue. Before you've had time to work out whether it's you who's gone mad, the credits roll and the action struggles to life. And aside from the double-headed plasticine giant snail that terrorises our heroes, you also get the added double bonus of having both the original actors voices AND the dubbed voices at the same time. Pure genius. The sad thing for fans of this kind of fare is that I've only ever seen one copy, so the chances of ever seeing it yourself is highly unlikely. Perhaps I own the only copy in existence.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The description of the poor special effects and awful sound track in the first 15 minutes sounds like a trainwreck that could be entertaining in its own right. The mention of the double-headed plasticine giant snail and the simultaneous original and dubbed voices adds to the hilarity. It seems like a movie that is so bad it's good, and I can see how it would have a certain charm for fans of this type of cheesy cinema.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the description of the movie's flaws may make it sound comically bad, I find it hard to believe that such poor quality would be enjoyable to watch. The idea of enduring such terrible special effects and sound for even 15 minutes does not sound appealing to me. Additionally, the fact that the reviewer has only seen one copy and doubts the chances of others seeing it suggests that the movie may not be worth seeking out, even for its unintentional humor.

review: The silent one-panel cartoon Henry comes to Fleischer Studios, billed as 'The world's funniest human' in this dull little cartoon. Betty, long past her prime, thanks to the Production Code, is running a pet shop and leaves Henry in charge for far too long -- five minutes. A bore.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The cartoon sounds uninteresting and lacking in humor. It's disappointing to see beloved characters like Betty not being utilized effectively. Overall, it seems like a forgettable experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the cartoon may not have been the most engaging, it could still hold some nostalgic value for fans of the characters or the studio. Sometimes simplicity can be charming, and not every cartoon needs to be fast-paced or filled with gags to be enjoyable.

review: William Russ is the main character throughout this made for TV movie. He left his family behind to only reappear and begin paying off his debts. But he tries to keep away from his family. Thats where Peter Falk (Colombo) comes in, playing several different roles, to convince him to come home. The story is average and they actually managed to get a former star (Peter Falk) and use him to a fairly nice degree. But William Russ wasn't truly a star. However, it appears his acting is still OK. I found the delivery and story very cheesy in how everything was predictable. In fact, the last 20 minutes I could almost dictate word for word before it happened. A good movie should never be like that. Overall, it was a sub-par movie. In a letter grading system, it would receive a 'D'.
agree: I agree with the review that the movie was sub-par and the story was predictable. The use of a former star like Peter Falk was a nice touch, but the overall delivery and predictability of the plot made it fall short of being engaging. A good movie should keep the audience guessing and not be easily predicted.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment of William Russ's acting. While the story may have been predictable and the overall movie sub-par, it's unfair to solely criticize Russ's acting abilities. Even if he wasn't a big star, his performance being 'OK' suggests he did a decent job with the material he was given. It's important to acknowledge the efforts of all actors in a production, regardless of the overall quality of the film.

review: From a poorly contrived plot line that makes almost no sense to bad dialogue and disjointed scenes to the ultimate downer, bad acting (even Peter Falk can't find his way) 'Finding John Christmas' is better left lost. Ms. Bertinelli's performance is without depth or emotion as are her co-stars, William Russ as brother Hank and David Cubitt as love interest Noah. Jennifer Pisana as Soccoro, the daughter of single dad Noah is almost unbearable to watch let alone listen to singing. But who can blame them with material like this. Michael J. Murray's script is juvenile at best. Each year at this time I search the TV guides and wait anxiously for some of the really classic Christmas and inspirational holiday films to appear on the small screen. Films like 'Miracle on 34th Street', Ernst Lubitsch's delightful 'The shop around the corner' and, of course the 1951 version of 'Scrooge'. There's Frank Capra's classics 'It's a wonderful life' and 'Meet John Doe'. Hey, forget the classics. What about 'Home Alone' or ' Home for the Holidays' with Holly Hunter and a great performance by Robert Downey Jr.? My present to you is by way of advice. Your time would be better spent searching out these films than finding 'Finding John Christmas'. Merry Christmas!
agree: I completely agree with this review. 'Finding John Christmas' was a disappointment on all fronts - from the weak plot to the lackluster performances. The comparison to classic holiday films like 'It's a Wonderful Life' and 'Miracle on 34th Street' only highlights how far off the mark this movie was. It's definitely not worth anyone's time during the holiday season.
disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with the review. While 'Finding John Christmas' may not have lived up to the standards of classic holiday films, it still had its own charm and heartwarming moments. The performances, while not outstanding, were decent enough to convey the emotions of the story. Sometimes, a simple and feel-good holiday movie like this can be a nice change of pace from the more serious classics.

review: I never like to comment on a good film but when it comes to a bad movie, I gotta come really hard on it. Talking about Vivah, this guy, Sooraj Badjatya, seems to have completely lost it. After success of Hum Aapke Hain Kaun, he thought he can make money with cheesy wedding videos. Vivah is so so cheesy that Badjatyas have left Johars and Chopras behind. There was not a single moment during the movie where I can say 'Oh! at least this thing is good'. Aloknath does cliché in a role of Girl's father, Shahid kapoor looks fat and Shahrukhed, Amrita rao is another disaster in addition to ugly looking sets, bad costumes, hackneyed storyline, monstrous stepmother, trying-hard-to-act actors, cacophonous background music, cheap soundtracks. Now the spoiler, I'm warning you guys that as happens in all his other movies, after a calamitous incidence movie ends on a happy note.
agree: I completely agree with this review. Vivah was indeed a disappointment with its cheesy and cliché elements. The performances, sets, costumes, and storyline all fell short, making it a difficult movie to sit through. Sooraj Badjatya's attempt to recreate the success of his previous films like Hum Aapke Hain Kaun fell flat, and the movie failed to deliver any redeeming qualities.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While Vivah may not have been a groundbreaking film, it did have its moments of charm and sweetness. The performances, especially by Alok Nath and Amrita Rao, added a certain warmth to the movie. The film's focus on family values and traditions resonated with some audiences, making it a decent watch for those who appreciate a more traditional and melodramatic style of storytelling.

review: I won't say this movie was bad, but it wasn't good either. I expected something good but I guess Hum Aapke Hain Kaun was much better than this. This was completely old fashioned. At every stage of this movie, I hoped for some twist and what do I get? The girl gets burned and wins her aunt's love. Despite of being engaged, they have to take permission for every little move they make. They are so darn shy even after so many meetings. I expected the aunt to be much more brutal than that. All she did was crib madly. Hey, we have kids too, but we don't watch them and have tears in our eyes always. This movie is a dream. Happy family, one cruel woman, good in-laws and a man who loves her to death. In HAHK Anupam Kher was the poor bride's father and now it's vice versa. And I somehow knew that Mohnish Behl would be in this movie. Anyway I believe I wasted my time. I give it a 2/10.
agree: I agree with the review that this movie fell short of expectations and was old-fashioned. The lack of twists and the predictable storyline were disappointing. The characters' behavior, such as the excessive shyness and constant need for permission, felt unrealistic. The portrayal of the aunt as merely a complainer rather than a more complex character was a missed opportunity. The reviewer's comparison to Hum Aapke Hain Kaun highlights the shortcomings of this film.
disagree: I disagree with the review's overall negative assessment of the movie. While it may not have met the reviewer's expectations, it still had some redeeming qualities. The depiction of a happy family dynamic, albeit idealized, can be comforting and enjoyable for some viewers. The presence of familiar actors like Mohnish Behl can add a sense of nostalgia for fans. Additionally, the emotional moments in the film, such as the protagonist winning her aunt's love, can resonate with audiences looking for a heartwarming story.

review: A Cinderella story made for adults who live in dreamland. The romance is very unrealistic, fluttery, lovey dovey, perfect etc. The Cinderella plot till the very end and Shahid Kapoor is the only reason for my stars. If you're looking for a dreamy romance with a twist, this is definitely you're movie, but for the rest of us real world people, I'd highly recommend saving your three hour watch time. Wake up people! Four out of the five people that saw the film with me would not recommend the film. We had a great time bashing majority of the unrealistic scenes. Maybe I'm missing something.. I just can't believe a movie like this can beat a classic like HDDCS!!
agree: I completely agree with this review. The romance in the movie was indeed very unrealistic and overly perfect. While Shahid Kapoor's performance was commendable, the overall plot felt like a fairy tale designed for those who prefer dreamy, idealistic love stories. The criticism of the unrealistic scenes is valid, and I also believe that for viewers seeking a more grounded and relatable storyline, this movie may not be the best choice.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the romance may have been portrayed in a dreamy and idealistic manner, that is often the appeal of such films for many viewers. Not every movie needs to mirror reality, and the escapism provided by a Cinderella story can be enjoyable for those looking for a break from the real world. Additionally, the mention of Shahid Kapoor's performance as a standout factor suggests that there are elements of the movie worth appreciating beyond just the romantic plot. Ultimately, personal preferences play a significant role in how one perceives a film, and for fans of romantic fantasies, this movie could still be a worthwhile watch.

review: After being hugely entertained by Mr. Brosnan's performance as a cad in "The Tailor of Panama" (which I rate 10/10 across the board: casting, acting, script, story, editing, pace, music, emotional impact, etc.), I enthusiastically anticipated this film. I was hugely disappointed. It is a script reading not a film, vulgar for the sake of being vulgar, bankrupt in every way that "The Tailor of Panama" is rich and satisfying. Blame it on the screen writing and directing. I sat in the theater waiting for the "good part;" it never came. I neither laughed nor cried, although one line of dialog did make me smile. Worth $7? Hardly.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The disappointment felt after enjoying Brosnan's performance in "The Tailor of Panama" was palpable in this film. The lackluster script and direction made it feel like a mere script reading rather than a compelling movie. The excessive vulgarity seemed forced and devoid of substance, in stark contrast to the richness and satisfaction of the previous film. The anticipation for a standout moment was never fulfilled, leaving the viewer devoid of emotional engagement. The assessment of the film's value being far from worth the price is spot on.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I understand the disappointment stemming from high expectations after enjoying Brosnan's performance in "The Tailor of Panama," I found this film to offer a different experience. The raw and unapologetic portrayal, though vulgar at times, added a layer of authenticity and grit to the story. The script reading style may have been intentional to focus on the characters and their interactions, providing a unique perspective. The absence of traditional emotional cues like laughter or tears could be seen as a deliberate choice to challenge conventional storytelling. Despite its flaws, I believe the film had its own merits and offered a thought-provoking experience.

review: The fine cast cannot uplift this routine tale of a secretary murdered by her married paramour. In fact there are more questions than answers in this one-sided tale of romance and murder; and since we are only provided with the prosecution's side, none of these questions will be answered. This is the type of fare that appeals to the 'He Woman, Man Hater' clubs of America. As presented, it is the tale of an innocent woman who just happens to be 'caught up' in a romance with a married, high-profile attorney. Is it possible that IF, she had not been two timing her boy friend and having an affair with a married man, the whole nasty murderous, sordid incident could have been avoided? When you watch this, don't worry about going to the 'fridge, you won't miss anything.
agree: I agree with the review that the movie fails to provide a balanced perspective and leaves many questions unanswered. The portrayal of the characters and the storyline seem one-sided, which can be frustrating for viewers looking for a more nuanced exploration of the events. The focus on the secretary's relationship with a married man without delving into other aspects of the story limits the depth of the narrative.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assertion that the movie caters to 'He Woman, Man Hater' clubs. While the film may have its flaws in terms of storytelling and character development, it is unfair to dismiss it as appealing only to a specific group. The critique of the secretary's actions and the lack of exploration of other perspectives may be valid, but it does not necessarily mean that the movie is targeted at a particular audience.

review: This film is a calculated attempt to cash in the success of Sex in the City and Four Weddings and a Funeral. In fact, if they'd called it Sex at a Funeral, they might have done better at the box office. But the film falls between two stools and can't get up. The characters spout improbably bright dialog, but never act in any way remotely recognizable as human. One arbitrary, senseless action follows another to advance what passes for a plot, and one soon tires of the falsity of the whole enterprise. Andie MacDowell gets points for acting her little heart out, but the performing honors are stolen by Imelda Staunton, as of all things, a police detective (don't they have a height requirement over there?). Ms. Staunton seems unable to make a false move. Would that we could say the same about the writer-director. If Notting Hill annoyed you as being bogus, stay away from this one. Phonus bolognus on the half-shell.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The film does feel like a cheap attempt to replicate the success of other popular movies, and the characters come across as unrealistic and unrelatable. The plot seems to rely on contrived and nonsensical actions, making it hard to invest in the story. Andie MacDowell's efforts are commendable, but Imelda Staunton truly shines in her role. Overall, the film falls flat in its execution and fails to deliver a genuine and engaging experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have drawn inspiration from other successful movies, it's unfair to dismiss it as a mere cash grab. The characters, though perhaps exaggerated, bring a certain charm and wit to the screen. The plot, though unconventional, keeps the audience engaged with its unexpected twists and turns. Andie MacDowell and Imelda Staunton both deliver strong performances that add depth to the story. Despite its flaws, the film offers a unique and entertaining take on romantic comedy that may appeal to a different audience.

review: This had to be one of the worst films ever. When Kate shows up and Jed is with a bunch of guys and they all start clapping...so Hollywood. Another bad scene was when Kate was running her hands over the pavement it appeared that she was examining the texture of the pavement. Andie's acting is so bad in this film - I could not connect with them or feel there love for each other. The other 2 women however were very good and overshadowed Andie. Anyway this was such a campy movie. I usually like these type of films but I just couldn't get into this film. Too many unlikely situations and again Andie's acting didn't help the film. Also, she is all gums. Lancome must put her makeup on with a putty knife because she looks glamorous in the commericals.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The scenes mentioned felt overly dramatic and unrealistic, and Andie's acting did not seem convincing. The other actresses in the film definitely outshined her, and the overall campy feel of the movie was off-putting. The criticism of Andie's appearance and makeup also resonates with my viewing experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While some scenes may have felt exaggerated, I found the Hollywood elements to be part of the film's charm. Andie's acting, though criticized, may have been intentional to fit the tone of the movie. Additionally, the chemistry between the characters, including Kate and Jed, felt genuine to me. The critique on Andie's appearance seems irrelevant to the film's quality and storytelling.

review: This starts off bad, what with the three women acting like simpering junior high school wussies sitting around giggling with their gin, endless cigarettes and a caramel chocolate treat for the one who tells the best 'man' story, and then it gets worse -=- spoiler alert =-= what with Andie's character falling for the young organ player who used to be her student when he was 14 (she's the headmistress of an English school, believe it or not), only to have him destroyed thanks to her bitch-from-hell 'girlfriend' . ..and then from there, it's basically unwatchable claptrap: she forgives her 'friend' and has the organ player's love child and the 3 women end up as they started, drinking more gin and smoking more cigarettes blah blah blah. Andie's character throws the caramel chocolates out in the street, in a pathetic attempt to symbolize growth. Have mercy.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The portrayal of the characters and the storyline seem unrealistic and unappealing. The relationships and decisions made by the characters are hard to relate to, making the movie difficult to watch.
disagree: I disagree with the review. While the beginning may have been off-putting, the development of the characters and their relationships could have provided a deeper insight into human complexities. The unconventional storyline may have been an attempt to challenge traditional narratives and offer a unique perspective on growth and forgiveness.

review: This was awful. Andie Macdowell is a terrible actress. So wooden she makes a rocking horse look like it could do a better job. But then remember that turn in Four Weddings, equally as excruciating. Another film that portrays England as full of Chocolate box cottages, and village greens. I mean that school, how many schools apart from maybe Hogwarts look like that? The twee police station looked like the set from Heartbeat ( a nauseating British series set in the 60s).This film just couldn't make its mind up what it wanted to be- a comedy or a serious examination of the undercurrents in women's friendships. If it had stuck to the former then the graveyard sex scenes and the highly stupid storming of the wedding might just have worked( i say just). But those scenes just didn't work with the tragedy in the second half. I also find it implausible that Kate would ever speak to Molly again after her terrible behaviour. A final note- what is a decent actress like Staunton doing in this pile of poo? Not to mention Anna Chancellor. Macdowell should stick to advertising wrinkle cream.
agree: I completely agree with this review. Andie Macdowell's performance was indeed lacking, and the film's inconsistent tone made it difficult to fully engage with the story. The mix of comedy and serious themes felt disjointed, and the implausibility of certain character interactions detracted from the overall viewing experience. The presence of talented actresses like Staunton and Chancellor only highlighted the shortcomings of the film.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While Andie Macdowell's performance may not have been the strongest, I believe that the film's blend of comedy and serious themes added depth to the story. The contrast between the lighter moments and the more tragic elements could be seen as a reflection of the complexities of women's friendships. Additionally, the unique setting and visual style of the film, while somewhat stereotypical, added to its charm and whimsy.

review: Caught this on IFC yesterday, and can't believe the positive reviews! Am I the only one who thought these 'ladies' were anything but? Kate tells Jed she could get fired because she's supposed to be a pillar of the community, but puts out for him! Then they suddenly decide they're in love? And she's SO devastated over his death, she doesn't go to his funeral, much less, tell his family the 'good news'! By the way, how did an American get to be the headmistress of a very proper British school? Janine should have been kicked off the force for her inexcusable abuse of power, but nothing happens! And she winds up boffing a con she brought in for questioning! And the less said about Molly, the better! As for the guilt Janine and Molly feel over Jed, please! It's the punk's own damn fault he got turned into roadkill! Where's the guilt over poor Gerald, who gets puked on? If only I could do the same to the bozos behind this 'movie'!
agree: I completely agree with this review. The characters' actions and decisions in the movie were unrealistic and inconsistent. The lack of consequences for their questionable behavior was frustrating to watch. The storyline seemed disjointed and the characters lacked depth.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the characters' actions may have been questionable, I believe it added to the complexity of the story. The film's portrayal of flawed characters grappling with guilt and consequences made it more engaging and thought-provoking. The unconventional relationships and unexpected twists kept me intrigued throughout.

review: I thought it was a New-York located movie: wrong! It's a little British countryside setting. I thought it was a comedy: wrong! It's a drama.... Well, up to the last third, because after the story becomes totally 'abracadabrantesque', the symbolic word for a French presidential mandate. It means, close to nonsense even it the motives would like to bring a sincere feeling. What Do I have left? Maybe, a good duo of actress: Yes, I know, they are 3 friends, but the redhead policewoman is a bit invisible for me. The tall doctoress surprises by her punch, and McDowell delivers a fine acting as usual, all in delicate, soft and almost mute attitude. This gentleness puzzles me, because as other fine artists or directors, the same pattern is repeating over and over. In her case, it's like, whatever the movie, it's always the same character defined by her feelings, her values, who lives infinite different stories. I still don't know how to set the limit (or the fusion) between the artists and the works. Another positive side of this movie is its feminine touch & the interesting different points of view. The women have each their own way of living, even if they are all single. It brings a lot of tolerance and learning to witness how a same and unique reality can be perceived in as many ways as people. Finally, the movie is quite viewable, but the great final cuts the desire of a next vision.
agree: I agree with the review that the movie offers a unique perspective on women's lives and relationships, showcasing different points of view and bringing a sense of tolerance and learning. The portrayal of the characters and their individual ways of living adds depth to the story and makes it engaging for viewers.
disagree: I disagree with the review's criticism of the movie becoming 'abracadabrantesque' towards the end. While the shift in tone may have been unexpected, it could be seen as a creative choice to add depth and complexity to the storyline. The movie's ability to surprise and challenge the audience's expectations can be a positive aspect, rather than a negative one.

review: Was this meant to be a comedy or a serious drama? This film starts with a light-hearted banter between three women. Fine. It moves into a conflict between the women when one of them meets a man. Fine. There are a few antics between them. Fine. But when the plot thickens and finally becomes black I started to wonder whether I had misinterpreted the first part of the movie. It continues in this vein for a while until, in the end, it tries to go back to the original light-hearted banter. But by now it's too late. It's hard to see why these women would still be talking to one another and the finale is unconvincing. Truly a lesson (for British filmmakers anyway) of how not to make films. Difficult to see how the producers ever convinced themselves this film would work. And the box office proved it to be a real flop, because I'd never heard of this film until this weekend (four years after its release).
agree: I completely agree with this review. The film's tonal shifts were confusing and made it hard to connect with the characters. The attempt to blend comedy with serious drama fell flat, resulting in an unconvincing and unsatisfying finale. It's clear that the filmmakers struggled to find a cohesive direction for the story, leading to a disappointing viewing experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have had tonal inconsistencies, I believe that the blend of light-hearted banter and darker themes could have been intentional to create a complex narrative. The evolution of the characters and their relationships could have been meant to challenge traditional storytelling conventions. While the finale may not have been perfect, I appreciate the attempt to explore different emotional layers within the story.

review: Andie McDowell is beautiful as the 40-ish woman whose late start at a serious relationship leads her to a considerably younger man and a subsequent falling-out with 2 long-time best girlfriends. Seeing a gigolo/gold-digger in the sincere young man, the 'girl-friends', dead-set on terminating this 'silly relationship', go over and beyond the call of duty in 'helping out' their friend (who obviously is blinded by this gigolo's tricky game). A short succession of situations is absolutely ridiculous. Far-fetched no longer covers it. Without these unbelievable scenes, there may have been hope for a sweet love story. Instead, all the viewer is left with is an involuntary shaking of head -- these things just don't happen! Without giving away cliff-hanger details, I warn the viewer of having high expectations for this film; most (like me) will be very disappointed. On a scale of 1 to 10, this one ranks a weak 4 with me. There is much better material out there. This one isn't worth your time.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The plot seems far-fetched and the situations portrayed are just too ridiculous to be believable. The characters' actions and decisions are hard to relate to, and it ultimately detracts from what could have been a sweet love story. I also found myself shaking my head at the unbelievable events that unfolded. This movie definitely fell short of expectations and I would not recommend it to others.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I understand the criticism of the unrealistic situations in the film, I believe that Andie McDowell's performance as the lead character was captivating and brought depth to the story. The dynamics between the characters, though exaggerated at times, added an interesting layer to the narrative. Additionally, the exploration of relationships and age dynamics could be seen as thought-provoking rather than purely ridiculous. While the movie may not be perfect, I think it still has some redeeming qualities that make it worth a watch for those interested in unconventional romantic comedies.

review: And then he gets run over by a truck." Can you imagine a screenwriter actually submitting a script with this plot element? Up to then, its a comedy that intends to be frothy, but lacks any real fizz. Everybody but Jed is just annoying. And then they kill Jed, and everybody's sad, until the end where the gals learn to love one another and be supportive, instead of destructive. I give it 2 ugh's.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The sudden and tragic death of Jed felt out of place in what seemed to be a light-hearted comedy. The characters were not very likable, and the overall tone of the film was inconsistent. The ending did little to redeem the earlier flaws in the story.
disagree: I disagree with this review. While the death of Jed may have been unexpected, it added a layer of depth and emotion to the film. The characters may have been flawed, but their growth and development throughout the story were compelling. The ending, where the women learn to support each other, was a poignant and satisfying conclusion.

review: The worst thing about Crush is not that it's acted pretty bad, or that the plot is virtually non-existent, and it's not even that bad that the camerawork could have been better. No, the worst part of this movie is that it has a few absolutely brilliant moments that keep you hoping that there are more to come. But in the end, it's too little, too late. If you are a fan of violin-music and cheap tearjerking scenes of 40+ women crying and hugging and talking about babies and marriage - then by all means, don't miss it. I myself am not exactly thrilled to see the things listed above in a movie, and as a result I had a pretty horrible time. The few absolutely brilliant jokes can not make up for the rest of it. The verdict: 4/10. Guilty of wasting my time.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie Crush had a few moments that showed potential, but overall, it failed to deliver a compelling story or engaging performances. The excessive focus on clichéd emotional scenes and lackluster execution made it a disappointing experience. The reviewer's assessment of the film aligns with my own feelings about it.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review of Crush. While I acknowledge that the movie may have had some shortcomings in terms of acting and plot, I found the moments of brilliance to be significant enough to redeem the overall viewing experience. The emotional depth portrayed through the characters and the impactful scenes resonated with me, making it a worthwhile watch despite its flaws. I believe that the reviewer may have overlooked the value of these poignant moments in their assessment.

review: Not a 'woman film' but film for the gang. One of the worst films ever made by a male director about woman. Director Andy McKay simply doesn't know woman. Peaks of bad taste, American Pie's humor style, crude story, no sense, groundless story, refuted characters. Vulgar fantasies came to life on screen. Insulting and definitely not funny. I wonder how three good actresses accepted to take part in it.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The film was indeed a disappointing portrayal of women and lacked depth and sensitivity in its storytelling. The humor was tasteless and the characters felt shallow and unrealistic. It's surprising that talented actresses would choose to be a part of such a project.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may not have resonated with everyone, it's important to acknowledge that humor and storytelling preferences vary among audiences. Some viewers may find the film's humor and characters entertaining, even if it may not align with everyone's tastes. It's possible that the film was intended for a specific audience that appreciates this style of comedy.

review: As a single woman over 40, I found this film extremely insulting and demeaning to single women over 40, not to mention every other woman, of any age. It was a sad, pathetic attempt by a man to write and direct a 'chick flick', and it failed miserably. Andy McDowell isn't much of an actress to begin with, but given the non-existent 'plot' (I hate to even refer to it as a plot) in this, she didn't have a chance. There was no character development, no reason to feel sympathy/empathy for any of the characters, and no attempt to make the film in any way realistic or believable. And then there's the obligatory male-fantasy of an attractive straight woman suddenly deciding to give lesbianism a try -- PLEASE. Not only do I wish I could get my money back for the DVD rental, I also want those 112 minutes of my life back. What a ripoff.
agree: I completely understand your perspective on this film. It's disappointing when movies resort to tired stereotypes and fail to provide meaningful character development. The lack of realism and believability can definitely detract from the overall viewing experience. It's frustrating when a film aimed at a specific demographic ends up being more demeaning than empowering.
disagree: While I respect your opinion, I found this film to be a refreshing take on relationships and self-discovery. The exploration of unconventional themes and character choices can be seen as a bold move rather than a failure. Andy McDowell's performance, though subjective, may have resonated with some viewers. Sometimes, films that challenge traditional narratives can spark important conversations and offer a different perspective on storytelling.

review: I was gifted with this movie as it had such a great premise, the friendship of three women bespoiled by one falling in love with a younger man. Intriguing. NOT! I hasten to add. These women are all drawn in extreme caricature, not very supportive of one another and conspiring and contriving to bring each other down. Anna Chancellor and Imelda Staunton could do no wrong in my book prior to seeing this, but here they are handed a dismal script and told to balance the action between slapstick and screwball, which doesn't work too well when the women are all well known professionals in a very small town. And for intelligent women they spend a whole pile of time bemoaning the lack of men/sex/lust in their lives. I felt much more could have been made of it given a decent script and more tension, the lesbian sub-plot went nowhere and those smoking/drinking women (all 3 in their forties???) were very unrealistic - even in the baby scene - screw the baby, gimme a cigarette! Right. Like I said, a shame of a waste. 4 out of 10.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie had a promising premise but failed to deliver on its potential. The characters were poorly developed and the script did not do justice to the talented actresses involved. The portrayal of women in the film was disappointing, with unrealistic behaviors and lack of depth. The missed opportunities and lack of meaningful plot development left much to be desired. I would also rate it a 4 out of 10.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have had its flaws, I found the premise to be engaging and the dynamic between the three women to be interesting. The performances by Anna Chancellor and Imelda Staunton were commendable, despite the limitations of the script. The blend of slapstick and screwball comedy added a unique touch to the film, and I appreciated the attempt to explore themes of friendship and love. While not perfect, I believe the movie deserves more credit than a 4 out of 10 rating.

review: The Crush is a pleasant enough 40-something friends romantic chick flick for the first two-thirds or so, as it tries to be a Brit 'Sex and the City'. I particularly enjoyed the turn-around of the trophy young hunk whose character is not much fleshed out. They sure make a lot more deal of young man/older woman than was made of the opposite in either version of 'Sabrina' or with the Douglas/Zeta-Jones or Dion/Svengali nuptials. Surrounding Andie MacDowell as an ex-pat are welcome familiars from Brit dramas and comedies.
agree: I agree with the review that the plot twists towards the end feel very deus ex machina and that the writer/director being male may have influenced the storytelling. The idea of the film potentially exploring the lives of three gay men coming out in relation to their lovers and at work sounds like it could have added more depth and interest to the movie.
disagree: I disagree with the review's suggestion that the movie would have been better as a story about three gay men. While that could have been an interesting concept, the film as it is, focusing on the dynamics between the characters in a romantic setting, has its own charm and appeal. The portrayal of relationships and age dynamics in The Crush is engaging in its own right.

review: It MIGHT have been a good movie if it had explored something more interesting rather than just the surface of a lesbian relationship. It is quite predictable, not mentioning that the two girls resemble the Russian group t.A.T.u. There is nothing original in this movie to support it so they had to use something which is already famous. You know the recipe. The other actors... well, I just don't know what their role is supposed to be. Most of them are well-known people in Romania and I must mention some of them are not even actors (e.g. Mihaela Radulescu). So to summarize it: 'girl band t.A.T.u.' + desperate/publicity needing 'actors' + a non-existing plot + the occasion to use bad language in order to shock = Love Sick. Too bad... the idea was good, though... and I am seriously holding myself from commenting the title...
agree: I agree with the review that the movie could have been more engaging if it delved deeper into the themes beyond just the surface of a lesbian relationship. The predictability and lack of originality in the storyline are valid points. The resemblance to t.A.T.u. and the use of well-known personalities as actors without clear roles also detract from the overall impact of the film.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assertion that the movie had to rely on using something already famous like t.A.T.u. to support its lack of originality. While the film may have missed the mark in exploring deeper themes, the use of familiar faces from Romania's entertainment scene could have added a unique element to the storytelling. Additionally, the inclusion of non-actors like Mihaela Radulescu could have brought a fresh perspective to the film.

review: This is a movie that relies solely on the somewhat controversial image of incest and lesbianism to get noticed. The dialogs are pathetic and the sensuality of the 'sex scenes' is absolutely absent. The acting and the dialog are more suited for high-school children, yet the subject is intended for adult audiences. It is a gutless and shallow movie. It could have been way better if it had a story and more drama. Ah and on top of that, one more thing: why are inner monologues so excessively used? Makes it seem so cheap. All in all an embarrassing movie for Romanian cinema as well as for mature audiences attempting to view it. I know the means are scarce but, that is not always an excuse for a movie flopping as this one does. And please start using some good actors in your movies and stop recycling them from musicians (Tudor Chirila) - they can't act!
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie's reliance on controversial themes without substance, poor dialogue, lack of sensuality in the 'sex scenes,' and inadequate acting make it a disappointing and shallow experience. The excessive use of inner monologues further detracts from the overall quality of the film. It's a missed opportunity for Romanian cinema and fails to engage mature audiences effectively.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have its flaws in terms of dialogue and execution, the exploration of controversial themes like incest and lesbianism can be a bold and thought-provoking choice in storytelling. The use of inner monologues, though excessive, could add depth to the characters and their motivations. Additionally, the casting of musicians like Tudor Chirila can bring a fresh perspective to acting and contribute to the diversity of performances on screen.

review: I am not so much like Love Sick as I image. Finally the film express sexual relationship of Alex, kik, Sandu their triangle love were full of intenseness, frustration and jealous, at last, Alex waked up and realized that they would not have result and future. Ending up was sad. The director Tudor Giurgiu was in AMC theatre on Sunday 12:00PM on 08/10/06, with us watched the movie together. After the movie he told the audiences that the purposed to create this film which was to express the sexual relationships of Romanian were kind of complicate. On my point of view sexual life is always complicated in everywhere, I don't feel any particular impression and effect from the movie. The love proceeding of Alex and Kiki, and Kiki and her brother Sandu were kind of next door neighborhood story. The two main reasons I don't like this movie are, firstly, the film didn't told us how they started to fall in love? Sounds like after Alex moved into the building which Kiki was living, then two girls are fall in love. It doesn't make sense at all. How a girl would fall in love with another girl instead of a man. Too much fragments, you need to image and connect those stories by your mind. Secondly, The whole film didn't have a scene of Alex and Kik's sexual intercourse, that 's what I was waiting for…. However, it still had some parts were deserved to recommend. The 'ear piercing' part was kind of interesting. Alex was willing to suffer the pain of ear piercing to appreciate kik's love. That was a touching scene which gave you a little idea of their love. Also, the scene of they were lying in the soccer field, the conversation express their loves were truthful and passionate.
agree: I agree with the review that the film lacked depth in portraying how the characters fell in love and the absence of a scene depicting Alex and Kik's sexual intercourse was disappointing. The fragmented storytelling made it challenging to fully connect with the characters' emotions and motivations. The love triangle felt more like a cliché next-door neighborhood story rather than a complex exploration of relationships. The reviewer's points about the film's shortcomings are valid and reflect my own disappointment with the movie.
disagree: I disagree with the review's overall negative assessment of the film. While I acknowledge the valid criticisms

agree: I agree with the review that the film lacked depth in portraying the development of the relationships between the characters. The suddenness of the romantic connections felt unrealistic and left me questioning the believability of the story. Additionally, the absence of a crucial scene depicting Alex and Kik's sexual intimacy left a gap in understanding the depth of their relationship. While there were some touching moments in the film, overall, I found it difficult to fully connect with the characters and their experiences.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment of the film. I found the portrayal of the
