review: Considering that this movie had a serious and quite successful launching campaign, I would have expected something to be worth the fuzz...from the opening scene on (in which the two brothers 'sensually' caress each other, laying naked in a bed) it goes rapidly downwards...nothing to get the attention, not a mind-catching thing in the whole plot, baaad baad acting (a few minor exceptions, but artificiality is at its best). Incest and lesbianism are promising themes, but the script analyses none of the two in depth ( mind that a possible excuse of the makers, saying that they aimed for a subtle movie would be hilarious, unless subtle and superficial mean the same thing...). The too curious viewers will not get any interesting scene...at this point, that could have saved some of the movie...so you can imagine how bad it is. Many other things could be said...but please watch the movie yourselves...I am an egoist and I would like as many people as possible to waste about 1 1/2h of their lives...like I did :(
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie failed to live up to the expectations set by its marketing campaign and the initial premise. The lack of depth in exploring the themes of incest and lesbianism was disappointing, and the acting felt forced and artificial. It's a shame that such promising themes were not given the attention they deserved, making the overall viewing experience a letdown.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may not have delved deeply into the themes of incest and lesbianism, I believe that its subtlety added a layer of complexity to the storytelling. The opening scene, while provocative, set the tone for the complex relationship between the two brothers. The acting, though not perfect, had moments of authenticity that resonated with me. Overall, I found the movie to be a thought-provoking exploration of familial dynamics and sexuality.

review: Yes, indeed, it could have been a good movie. A love biangle, (sorry for the poetical license, but is not a triangle!) an interesting story, unfortunately badly told. The image is sometimes weird, sometimes OK, the picture looks crowded and narrow-sighted. The sound needs more attention (it usually does in Romanian movies), the light and color filters are sometimes badly chosen. The soundtrack is short and is not helping the action. About the acting... sorry but the best actress is the landlady. The others are acting immaturely and cannot convince the viewer. The acting is poetical when it should be realistic, and realistic when it should be poetical. It's a picture for adults, told by the children. Bother only if extremely curious.
agree: I agree with the review that the movie had potential but fell short in execution. The storytelling seemed lacking, the visuals and sound needed improvement, and the acting did not fully engage the audience. The criticism of the film being like a picture for adults told by children resonates with me, as it suggests a disconnect in the maturity and depth of the narrative.
disagree: I disagree with the review's harsh assessment of the movie. While there may have been flaws in the execution, the unique storytelling approach and unconventional visuals could have been intentional artistic choices. The portrayal of the characters as poetical rather than strictly realistic could have added depth and complexity to the narrative. Additionally, the perspective of the landlady as the standout actress could be seen as a refreshing and unexpected aspect of the film.

review: Closer to reality and containing more depth than 'Breakdance', Stan Lathan's 'Beat Street' is still a pretty dull show. Again this pic is really only cashing in on the 'breakin' craze but at least we get a little bit of entertainment from the plot, which concerns the lives of three young friends and a younger brother, all growing up in Queens, New York. Each has their own unique talent. One is a hustler, one a d.j., another an artist who creates 'burners', while little bro' Lee is a hot 'hip hop' dancer. Lathan is unable to generate any real audience interest in the story though, and his young cast are likewise struggling with their characters. Therefore it is left almost entirely to the funky music and the 'fresh' dancing to save the day. Choreography is again sharp for both club and street scenes, but this alone is not enough to lift 'Beat Street' to greater heights. Unfortunately the film really falls flat late on, after showing a glimmer of hope that it just might get interesting. Sunday, August 25, 1996 - Video
agree: I agree with the review that 'Beat Street' falls short in generating audience interest and fails to fully engage with its characters. While the music and dancing are entertaining, they are not enough to compensate for the lackluster storytelling and character development. The film misses the opportunity to delve deeper into the lives of the young friends and their talents, leaving the audience wanting more substance and depth.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment that 'Beat Street' is a dull show. While it may not reach the heights of some other films in the genre, the movie still offers a glimpse into the lives of young individuals in Queens, New York, each with their own unique talents. The choreography and music add energy and vibrancy to the film, providing entertainment value. While the storytelling may have its flaws, the film still manages to capture the essence of the 'hip hop' culture of the time and offers a window into a specific community and its creative expressions.

review: Maybe you shouldn't compare, but Wild Style and Style Wars are original Hip Hop. Beat Street does have a lot of the original artists of early Hip Hop, but they've been obviously made clear that this could be their big break, of course for some it was and that's nice. But if you view this as original Hip Hop Culture you're wrong. It's overproduced and has a Hollywood sauce. Rather look for the first two movies i mentioned. They have convey the grittiness that comes with life in the ghetto. Yes, the rating for this movie is low, but the reviews are mostly positive or even raving. This is probably because although the story, the acting, the dialogues and the direction all are dreadful, the music and dancing is what the people love about it. Me, i do love the dancing but at the time thought that electro was the death of Hip Hop (i was so glad when round '86 a new generation of now classic Hip Hop artists appeared, like Krs One, Public Enemy, Ultramagnetic Mc's, Jungle Brothers, Bizmarkie to name a few), and i still don't like most of the beats in this movie and that is why it doesn't work for me. I mean, Wild Style has not much of a story but the music there is great and authentic. Of course tastes differ and that's alright. But as far as i'm concerned, this movie is trash except for the break dancing and some of the music and so i can't rate it higher than a 4 out of ten.
agree: I agree with the reviewer that Beat Street may not capture the authentic grittiness of early Hip Hop culture and that it comes across as overproduced with a Hollywood touch. The comparison to Wild Style and Style Wars, which are seen as more authentic representations of Hip Hop, is valid. The focus on music and dancing in Beat Street seems to overshadow other aspects like story, acting, and dialogue.
disagree: I disagree with the reviewer's harsh assessment of Beat Street as 'trash.' While it may not fully capture the rawness of early Hip Hop culture, the movie still serves as a platform for showcasing original artists and their talents. The music and dancing elements, which the reviewer acknowledges as enjoyable, are integral to the film's appeal and should not be discounted entirely. Additionally, personal preferences for beats and music styles should not overshadow the

review: I could never stand watching Happy Days after Chachi joined the cast, so I knew I was in trouble when the best scene in this movie featured Scott Baio (a skateboard chase scene!). Jodie Foster in her first 'grown-up' role turns in her usual professional performance but that is no excuse for this boring mess. Two hours out of my life that I'll never get back! No noteworthy characters, unbelievable storyline, questionable editing and horrendous cinematography but worst of all, I couldn't have cared less. The story of California teens in the 1970's, where the kids live miserable lives and all their parents are idiots. Don't waste your time watching this ugly excuse for a movie.
agree: I completely understand where you're coming from. The movie failed to capture my interest as well, and I found it lacking in many aspects. The portrayal of California teens and their parents felt shallow and unconvincing, making it hard to invest in the characters or the storyline. The performances, including Jodie Foster's, couldn't salvage the weak script and uninspired direction. It's disappointing to see such potential wasted on a film that ultimately falls flat.
disagree: While I respect your opinion, I have to disagree with your assessment of the movie. I found the skateboard chase scene with Scott Baio to be a fun and exciting moment that injected some much-needed energy into the film. Jodie Foster's performance, as always, was captivating and added depth to her character. The portrayal of California teens in the 1970s may have been bleak, but it felt authentic and provided a unique perspective on that era. The film's flaws aside, I believe there were redeeming qualities that made it worth watching.

review: Horrible film with bits of the Ramones strewn about. Your worse than average 1970's/80's comedy format of the cool kids taking over the school with some whimsical plan. This movie is terrible. The plot consists of a girl who enjoys the Ramones and a school bent on fighting against their oppressive administration. Forget this movie and watch something like Wild Zero starring Guitar Wolf if you want an entertaining B movie. Terrible acting, terrible writing, terrible plot with the stamp of approval of the Ramones who probably needed some money quick so they said yes to this movie. That is the only logical thing I can think of because this movie blows.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie failed to deliver on multiple fronts, from the acting to the plot. The attempt to incorporate the Ramones felt forced and did not add any value to the overall experience. I would also recommend watching Wild Zero for a more entertaining B movie experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may not have been a masterpiece, it still had its charm and entertainment value. The incorporation of the Ramones' music added a unique element to the film, and the theme of rebellion against oppressive authority resonated with many viewers. The movie may not be for everyone, but it certainly has its merits.

review: This movie is a 90 minute Ramones concert with brief periods of stupidity and absolute boredom. What kind of high school is this anyway? Unless you are a major Ramones fan, DO NOT and I repeat DO NOT waste your time like I did. This is utterly unwatchable from start to finish. This movie should be called Ramone Fever. Everyone appears to like them in this movie. There is not a plot to be found in this flick. As far as teen comedies go, you are scraping the bottom of the barrel with this one.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie felt like a disjointed mess with no coherent plot and excessive focus on the Ramones concert. It failed to engage the audience and left me feeling bored and uninterested throughout.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. As a major Ramones fan, I found the concert sequences to be exhilarating and a highlight of the movie. While the plot may have been lacking, the energy and music of the Ramones made the film enjoyable for me. It's understandable that not everyone would appreciate this style of movie, but for fans of the band, it was a fun experience.

review: I gave this film 2 stars only because Dominic Monaghan actually put effort through in his acting. Everything else about this film is extremely amateur. Everything associated with the direction of this film was very poorly executed. Not only should the director rethink what she is doing for a life career but maybe she should watch a few films. As Dominic Monaghan is a very credible actor, placing him in a film of this caliber makes him look awful. Whomever the 'actor' was that played Jack's best friend should never have stepped in front of the camera. I didn't expect much from such a small film, but perhaps a little more time and effort should be put into the characters and their surroundings. Don't waste your time or money on this film (like I did) you will be sorely disappointed.
agree: I agree with the review that the film lacked quality in many aspects. The direction seemed amateurish and the overall execution was poor. While Dominic Monaghan's acting stood out, it was not enough to salvage the film. The criticism of the supporting cast and character development is valid, and I also believe that more effort should have been put into these areas. Overall, I share the sentiment that viewers may be disappointed by this film.
disagree: I disagree with the review's harsh criticism of the director and the suggestion that she should reconsider her career choice. While the film may have had its flaws, it is important to remember that filmmaking is a complex and challenging art form. Constructive feedback is valuable, but personal attacks on the director are unwarranted. Additionally, while the film may not have met the reviewer's expectations, it is subjective whether it is a complete waste of time and money for all viewers. Different people have different tastes, and some may still find value in the film despite its shortcomings.

review: This episode of TALES FROM THE CRYPT just recycles tired material involving the old 'Santa kills' theme while also adding the oft-used (add nauseum) woman-murders-her-husband-for-a-man-she's-been-cheating-with routine. It's essentially Trainor trying to find a way to avoid being caught with a dead body she kills while also keeping a safe distance from a maniac. There's nothing refreshing or new about this plot which pretty much goes through the motions. Not one of the show's highlights.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The episode felt like a rehash of overused themes and lacked any originality. The plot was predictable and failed to bring anything new to the table. It definitely falls short of being a standout episode in the series.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the episode may have utilized familiar themes, I found the tension between the wife, the Santa killer, and the daughter to be gripping and well-executed. The performances, especially by Mary Ellen Trainor and Larry Drake, added depth to the characters and kept me engaged throughout. I believe this episode offered a thrilling and suspenseful take on a classic storyline.

review: That's not the sound of bees, that's the effect induced by watching this extremely long, extremely boring, badly acted movie. How I ever made it through all 3 1/2 hours without falling asleep I'll never know. The plot is simple...3 thoroughly unlikable morons talk about sex for 3 1/2 hours. And you thought Rohmer was deadly. This is even worse, if that's possible.
agree: I must really be a masochist if I could watch this entire movie without turning it off...or killing someone.
disagree: I found the movie to be a captivating exploration of human relationships and desires. The lengthy runtime allowed for a deep dive into the characters' psyche and the dialogue about sex added layers to their personalities. The acting, though unconventional, felt raw and authentic, making the viewing experience engaging throughout.

review: Iberia is nice to see on TV. But why see this in silver screen? Lot of dance and music. If you like classical music or modern dance this could be your date movie. But otherwise one and half hour is just too long time. If you like to see skillful dancing in silver screen it's better to see Bollywood movie. They know how to combine breath taking dancing to long movie. Director Carlos Saura knows how to shoot dancing from old experience. And time to time it's look really good. but when the movie is one and hour it should be at least most of time interesting. There are many kind of art not everything is bigger then life and this film is not too big.
agree: I agree with the review that Iberia may be better suited for TV viewing rather than the silver screen due to its focus on dance and music. The mention of Bollywood movies as a better option for showcasing breathtaking dancing in a longer format is valid, as they excel in combining entertainment with dance sequences.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assertion that Iberia is not suitable for the silver screen. While the film may not be grandiose or larger than life, its focus on skillful dancing and the director's experience in capturing dance on film can still make it an engaging watch for those interested in classical music and modern dance.

review: That reviewers liked this movie surprises me. The plot is a muddle. The characters are wooden. Michael Bowen spends most of the film spying on the other characters and misjudging all of them. No one has any redeeming quality or point-of-interest. This is not an edgy work. It is not imaginative. It is not ironic. It is no clever. There is nothing straight forward about this tedious work. That is missed theatrical release is not surprise. That the 'This Network' airs it diminishes that venue. I definitely recommend turning to a rerun of the Garden Smart show on PBS or even a good informational if you encountered this mess on late night television. If you encounter it on daytime television, take a long walk. Even if you walk in smog, you will feel better not having suffered through this shambles. Life is short. This movie is long.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The plot was indeed confusing, the characters lacked depth, and the overall execution of the film fell flat. It's surprising that any reviewers found merit in this movie.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may not have been everyone's cup of tea, I found the unconventional storytelling and flawed characters to be intriguing. The lack of traditional redeeming qualities made it a refreshing departure from typical films.

review: This is a terrible movie, terrible script, bad direction and nonsensical ending. Also, bad performances, except from Clancy Brown who is criminally underused here, and Michael Pollard. Watching this movie was purgatory--you do it to unload enough bad movie karma to actually see a good one further down the line. The movie presents a father and son who look like they couldn't every possibly have been related. The part of the male lead is not well written and seems uncharismatic in this role. You can see the plot points a mile away. The actions of the female lead and that of her brother, the cop, also make no sense. So, a major action on her part at the end of the movie makes no sense script-wise.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie had a weak script, poor direction, and a confusing ending. The performances, with the exception of Clancy Brown and Michael Pollard, were lackluster. The characters lacked depth and the plot was predictable. The actions of the female lead and her brother, the cop, felt illogical and the overall viewing experience was disappointing.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may have had its flaws, I found the performances to be engaging, particularly from Clancy Brown and Michael Pollard. The relationship between the father and son, though not perfectly executed, still had moments of emotional resonance. The plot twists, while somewhat predictable, added tension to the story. I believe the actions of the characters, including the female lead and her brother, were in line with their motivations and added to the overall narrative.

review: Burt Kennedy used to be a very good director, but you'd never know it by this lumbering mess. Not only does this film look cheap, it IS cheap--most of the battle scenes are lifted from the far superior 'The Last Command' from 1955, and that footage, shot 32 years previously, looks more contemporary than anything in this picture. The few action scenes that were actually shot for this movie are disorganized, confused and incompetent, looking just as shoddy as the rest of the picture. This has the look and feel of a bad student film (and the budget didn't seem to be a whole lot more). It moves like molasses, the acting for the most part is either over-the-top ham or under-the-top comatose--although Raul Julia comes off better than most of the rest of the cast--and it's chock full of annoying historical inaccuracies. On top of that, it's WAY too long. If you're going to make a boring film, do it in an hour or so and get it over with--don't stretch it out over three hours, like this one does. If you want to see a good movie about the Alamo, check out John Wayne's 1960 version, or even the 1955 film from which this movie stole its action scenes. Hard to believe it took six producers to make a movie this lousy. Skip it.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The criticisms about the film looking cheap, the disorganized action scenes, and the historical inaccuracies are all valid points. The comparison to 'The Last Command' and the suggestion to watch John Wayne's 1960 version instead make sense. The length of the movie being too long also adds to the overall negative viewing experience. It's disappointing that a director like Burt Kennedy delivered such a lackluster film.
disagree: While I understand some of the criticisms in the review, I have to disagree with the overall assessment. I found the film to have a certain charm in its attempt to depict the historical events, even if inaccuracies were present. The performances, especially by Raul Julia, added depth to the characters. Additionally, I appreciated the homage to 'The Last Command' and saw it as a creative choice rather than a flaw. The pacing, although slow, allowed for a more immersive experience in the story. Overall,

review: While being a great James Arness western, this film has gone down as the worst Alamo film ever made. The story was terrible, inaccuracy all through it, and just downright untruths to boot! Continuity was cast to the four winds. Anybody catch the cannon sequence? The Mexicans were dumb enough to fire cannons that obviously had mud and ramrods still sticking out of the tubes. Come on! Then there is Brian Keith's ridiculous hat! Costumer must of been away or something. Or just out of their mind!
agree: I completely agree with this review. The inaccuracies and lack of attention to detail in this film were truly disappointing. The cannon sequence and Brian Keith's hat were particularly distracting and took away from the overall viewing experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have had some inaccuracies and continuity issues, I believe that the performances of the actors, especially James Arness, elevated the movie and made it an enjoyable watch despite its flaws.

review: This movie is flawed on many fronts. Like many before it, it portrays more of the mythology of the Alamo than the history. The production is poor, overall giving the impression of a welfare project for lots of actors who might have otherwise had to work on Hollywood Squares. This to me was the greatest flaw - I know the ages and general personalities of the real Alamo protagonists and the geriatric ensemble of TV actors chosen to portray them never let any hint of believability intrude. As a native Texan, I grew up with the mythology. I later learned more about the history. I can accept a decent production from either perspective (although I prefer more historical accuracy), but this never gave me a chance to enjoy it. Even John Wayne's or Fess Parker's versions had more life than this stolid mess, while being only slightly less accurate. Very disappointing - avoid it.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie failed to capture the essence of the historical events and instead relied heavily on mythological elements. The poor production quality and the lack of believability in the actors' portrayals further detracted from the overall viewing experience. As a viewer who values historical accuracy, I found this movie to be a major disappointment and would recommend avoiding it.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While I understand the importance of historical accuracy, I believe that movies can also be appreciated for their entertainment value and artistic interpretation. The portrayal of the Alamo events through a mythological lens can offer a unique perspective and engage audiences in a different way. Additionally, the choice of actors, regardless of their TV backgrounds, should not solely determine the success of a film. I found this movie to be an interesting take on the Alamo story and would encourage viewers to give it a chance.

review: Slow and riddled with inaccuracy. Over-looking its flaws this is still an interesting account of the famed and heroic siege of the Alamo during the Texas fight for independence from Mexico. James Arness as Jim Bowie. Brian Keith as Davy Crockett. Alec Baldwin as Col. Travis. Raul Julia as General Santa Anna. This made-for-TV project also stars David Ogden Stiers, Kathleen York and Jim Metzler. Very good original music by Peter Bernstein.
agree: I agree with the review. While the movie may have been slow and inaccurate at times, it still managed to capture the essence of the Alamo siege and the bravery of those involved. The casting choices were interesting and the music added to the overall atmosphere.
disagree: I disagree with the review. While the movie may have had its flaws, I found it to be a compelling and engaging portrayal of the Alamo siege. The performances by James Arness, Brian Keith, Alec Baldwin, and Raul Julia were captivating, and the original music by Peter Bernstein added depth to the story.

review: This film, The Alamo: Thirteen Days to Glory, is utter rubbish. The acting is awful, it is far too patriotic and its historical accuracy is not always at its best (Historians would have a field day). It does have a few good moments but not enough to keep interest because it is far too long. Rating * out of **********.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The acting was subpar, the patriotism felt forced, and the historical inaccuracies were glaring. The film failed to maintain interest due to its excessive length and lack of compelling moments.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have had its flaws, I found the story of The Alamo to be engaging and the performances to be decent. The patriotism may have been heavy-handed, but it added to the emotional impact of the story. Overall, I would rate it higher than * out of **********.

review: The story by Norman Maclean is a masterwork; Redford's film is a mediocrity. He adds banal scenes of the Maclean brothers going over a falls and of them double-dating in a seedy bar that were not even hinted at in the story. The cipher, Brad Pitt, trying to play the charismatic Paul Maclean, a genius outdoors, proves either risible or depressing, depending on what the original story meant to you. Some of the fly casting scenes are beautiful. Also, Tom Skerritt as the father and Craig Sheffer as Norman are strong and masculine, as men were once expected to be. None of the women make an impression in the film, which is regrettable, because Maclean loved the women in his story and made this clear, even poetic.
agree: I agree with the review that the film adaptation of Norman Maclean's story falls short of capturing the essence and depth of the original work. The additional scenes and portrayal of characters like Paul Maclean by Brad Pitt may not have done justice to the source material.
disagree: I disagree with the review's assessment of the film. While it may have deviated from the original story in some aspects, the beauty of the fly casting scenes and the strong performances by actors like Tom Skerritt and Craig Sheffer should be acknowledged. The portrayal of masculinity in the film could be seen as a reflection of the time period and the characters' relationships.

review: The only good part about this film is the beautiful scenery. This movie was long and boring. The minister should have retired from the pulpit the time his son Paul strayed from the teachings he proclaimed. How many times can his boys take the Lord's name in vain in this film being from a Presbyterian background? It doesn't fit. I wished Paul was swept down the river without a boat at the very beginning to spare us the silly, smirkish, selfish story of Paul (Brad Pitt). So Norm becomes a teacher and Paul becomes a compulsive gambler who Norm wants to rescue but doesn't-so what. It's very uninteresting. We see the prejudiced whites being stood up to by Paul because of his native American girl. That was the only part that had some interest and maybe could have been developed into a real 'wild western'. What we only see is a sleepy town where the two minister's sons have nothing to do but 1. Norm chase a lame girlfriend and deal with her family and 2.Paul make up dumb stories at the newspaper shop while scratching his head and take a lot of swigs and tie a lot of flies. I'd rather watch a show about fishing that that film again-which will be never.
agree: I agree with the review that the movie lacked depth and failed to engage the audience. The characters seemed uninteresting and the plotline was weak. The only redeeming quality was the beautiful scenery, but that alone couldn't save the film from being long and boring.
disagree: I disagree with the review's harsh criticism of the film. While it may not have been the most captivating story, the themes of family dynamics and standing up against prejudice were compelling. The portrayal of the Native American girl and the challenges faced by the minister's sons added depth to the narrative. Additionally, the performances by the actors, especially Brad Pitt, brought some emotional weight to the film.

agree: I completely agree with this review of 'A River Runs Through It'. While the cinematography and acting were impressive, the lack of a compelling story and the unrelatable characters made it a disappointing watch. The predictability of the ending also took away from any potential impact the film could have had.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review of 'A River Runs Through It'. While the story may not have been action-packed or filled with twists, the film beautifully captures the complexities of family dynamics and the struggles of finding one's place in the world. The slow pace and introspective nature of the narrative added to the overall atmosphere of the movie, making it a poignant and thought-provoking experience for those who appreciate character-driven stories.

review: I always felt that a good film should have a plot. This particular film was missing one, and I feel that it would have been more effective with a plot. This was made even worse by the fact that it seemed to go on forever; I was anxious for it to finally end. However, I just noticed that it was only 123 minutes long; it felt like four hours. Not only was there no plot but the film also lacked a notable conflict. It's not the worst movie I've seen, but I used to say that it was until I saw 'The Fast And The Furious'. So, don't think this review of mine is from someone who needs nothing but action. I actually hate most action films out today; it's just that this film is all the way on the other side of the spectrum. Not much really happens in this movie. However, the scenery and costumes were nice.
agree: I completely agree with this review. A film without a plot can feel aimless and lacking in substance. It's disappointing when a movie drags on without a clear direction or conflict to engage the audience. While aesthetics like scenery and costumes can be visually pleasing, they can't make up for a weak storyline.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While having a strong plot is important for many films, there are instances where a more atmospheric or character-driven approach can be effective. Not every movie needs a traditional plot with clear conflict to be engaging or thought-provoking. The focus on scenery and costumes could have been a deliberate choice by the filmmakers to create a specific mood or aesthetic.

review: This movie has beautiful scenery. Unfortunately it has no plot. In order to have a plot there must be a conflict. This movie had none. It spent two hours painting a beautiful scene and failed to ever place any activity in it. The picture tries to be artistic but fails to pay attentions to the fundamentals of story telling. If you love Montana scenery and fly fishing you will find some value in this film just don't expect a story. There isn't one.
agree: I completely agree with this review. While the scenery was stunning, the lack of a coherent plot or conflict made it difficult to stay engaged with the film. It felt like a missed opportunity to create a compelling story within such a beautiful setting.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have lacked a traditional plot structure, I found the focus on the Montana scenery and fly fishing to be a refreshing change from typical narratives. The beauty of the setting and the meditative quality of the film allowed me to appreciate it in a different way.

review: This movie has beautiful scenery. Unfortunately it has no plot. In order to have a plot there must be a conflict. This movie had none. It spent two hours painting a beautiful scene and failed to ever place any activity in it. The picture tries to be artistic but fails to pay attention to the fundamentals of storytelling. If you love Montana scenery and fly fishing you will find some value in this film just don't expect a story. There isn't one.
agree: I completely agree with this review. While the scenery was stunning, the lack of a coherent plot or conflict made the movie feel empty and unfulfilling. It's a shame that such beautiful visuals were not accompanied by a compelling story.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may have lacked a traditional plot structure with a clear conflict, I found the focus on the scenery and fly fishing to be a refreshing change of pace. Sometimes a film can be more about the experience and atmosphere rather than a traditional narrative, and I appreciated the artistic approach taken in this movie.

review: Sorry, gave it a 1, which is the rating I give to movies on which I walk out or fall asleep. In this case I fell asleep 10 minutes from the end, really, really bored and not caring at all about what happened next.
agree: I completely understand where you're coming from. A movie that fails to engage the audience and leaves them feeling bored is a major disappointment. Falling asleep during a film is a clear sign that it failed to capture your attention and failed to deliver an engaging story.
disagree: While I respect your opinion, I found the movie to be captivating and engaging throughout. The storyline kept me hooked, and I was invested in the characters and their journey. Sometimes different viewers have different preferences, and what may have bored you might have resonated with others.

review: I didn't know whether to laugh or cry at this misrepresentation of Canadian history, particularly the disservice done to the history of the Mounted Police in the Yukon.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie's portrayal of the Yukon and the Mounted Police is a disservice to Canadian history and lacks accuracy.
disagree: I disagree with this review. While the movie may have taken creative liberties with historical facts, it still provided an entertaining and engaging story for viewers.

review: The five or so really good westerns that Mann made are unequaled as an ensemble in Hollywood. Even John Ford never made that many with so much quality. The curious thing about them all is how uneven they are. Ford's My Darling Clementine is worth about two and a half of any of them. Or at least two. The real hero of them besides Mann and Stewart is Chase. Each of the five films of Mann have huge gaps, or is it six, lets see. Bend, Far, Man of the West, Furies, Winchester 73, and yep, six, Naked Spur. Each have magnificent scene after magnificent scene, with fairly glaring lapses. But The Far Country has huge, huge holes. It's mawkish, and really comes alive only when Stewart and Mc Entire are locking horns. The rest is pretty pedestrian, with the usual exception of Mann's camera. The Far Country has one amazing moment. And as usual it comes from Stewart. Nobody in the history of cinema ever received physical punishment with the authority of that man. But that was Mann's territory. What a great, great director. See every western he ever made. They are his real monuments, even if all are sketchy. But so what. When he gets roaring with his great scenes they are as good as anybody, including Ford. And his six westerns as an ensemble are the best ever done by anyone, period.
agree: I completely agree with the review. Anthony makes a compelling argument about the brilliance of Anthony Mann's westerns and the uneven yet captivating nature of his films. The analysis of the performances by actors like James Stewart and the intense physicality captured by Mann's camera work is spot on. Despite the flaws and gaps in some of the films, the reviewer rightly praises Mann's directorial prowess and the impact of his westerns as a whole.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I acknowledge the strengths of Anthony Mann's westerns and the impact of his direction, I believe that the assertion that his six westerns as an ensemble are the best ever done is a bit overstated. While Mann's films have their moments of brilliance, there are other directors and westerns that also deserve recognition for their contributions to the genre. Additionally, the review's comparison to John Ford's work may not fully capture the nuances and impact of Ford's films in the western genre.

review: Mann photographs the Alberta Rocky Mountains in a superb fashion, and Jimmy Stewart and Walter Brennan give enjoyable performances as they always seem to do. But come on Hollywood - a Mountie telling the people of Dawson City, Yukon to elect themselves a marshal (yes a marshal!) and to enforce the law themselves, then gunfighters battling it out on the streets for control of the town? Nothing even remotely resembling that happened on the Canadian side of the border during the Klondike gold rush. Mr. Mann and company appear to have mistaken Dawson City for Deadwood, the Canadian North for the American Wild West. Canadian viewers be prepared for a Reefer Madness type of enjoyable howl with this ludicrous plot, or, to shake your head in disgust.
agree: I completely agree with the reviewer's assessment of the historical inaccuracies in the film. It's disappointing when filmmakers take such liberties with historical events and locations, especially when it misrepresents a real place like Dawson City during the Klondike gold rush.
disagree: While I acknowledge the historical inaccuracies pointed out by the reviewer, I still found the film to be an enjoyable watch. The stunning cinematography of the Alberta Rocky Mountains and the performances by Jimmy Stewart and Walter Brennan were enough to keep me engaged despite the fictionalized elements of the plot.

review: This action Western starring James Stewart and an all-star cast in the scenic Northwest is filmed in great splendor, with fantastic scenery and costumes. The film offers plenty of action and adventure as Stewart plays a wealthy cattleman who clashes with a crooked government in the old Northwest.
agree: I agree with the review that the minor characters in the film are quite enjoyable. Walter Brennan, Royal Dano, Harry Morgan, and others add depth and entertainment value to the movie, making it worth watching.
disagree: I disagree with the review's criticism of the main character played by James Stewart. While the character may exhibit some cynical traits, his complexity and interactions with his partners add credibility and likability to his portrayal. The nuanced performance by Stewart elevates the character beyond being a one-dimensional hero.

review: This is the worst sequel on the face of the world of movies. Once again it doesn't make sense. The killer still kills for fun. But this time he is killing people that are making a movie about what happened in the first movie. Which means that it is the stupidest movie ever. Don't watch this. If you value the one precious hour during this movie then don't watch it. You'll want to ask the director and the person beside you what made him make it. Because it just doesn't combine the original makes of horror, action, and crime. Don't let your children watch this. Teenager, young child or young adult, this movie has that sort of impact upon people.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The plot of the movie sounds nonsensical and the premise of the killer targeting people making a movie about the first movie is indeed quite ridiculous. It seems like a lazy attempt to capitalize on the success of the original without adding anything of substance. I would definitely avoid watching this film based on this review.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the premise may sound far-fetched, sometimes sequels take creative risks to differentiate themselves from the original. The blend of horror, action, and crime genres could potentially offer a unique viewing experience. It's important to keep an open mind and judge the movie for its entertainment value rather than dismissing it outright based on initial impressions.

review: Ah, Channel 5 of local Mexican t.v. Everyday, at 2:00 a.m. they air Horror movies from the 70's to early 2000's. It was 'Return To Cabin By The Lake' the movie that aired yesterday. I regret for watching it. The original 'Cabin By The Lake' was a regularly popular low budgeter and it was good accepted. The problem is that this sequel is horrible, not even unintentionally funny and tries to imitate the original. Ugh. The plot is really stupid in all the sense of the word. The movie at some points looks like a soap-opera because of it's absurd dialogs, cinematography, and direction. My advice is : avoid this one at all costs. It's a movie that it shouldn't be watched by anyone. Not even for lovers of mediocre film-making. You have been warned.
agree: I completely agree with this review. 'Return To Cabin By The Lake' sounds like a disaster of a movie, trying to capitalize on the success of the original without bringing anything new or interesting to the table. The criticisms of the plot, dialogue, cinematography, and direction all point to a film that is best avoided. Thanks for the warning!
disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with this review. While 'Return To Cabin By The Lake' may not have lived up to the original and may have its flaws, sometimes a cheesy horror movie can still be entertaining in its own way. It's possible that some viewers might enjoy it for its campy charm or unintentional humor. It's always worth giving a movie a chance and forming your own opinion, even if it's not a critical darling.

review: Return to Cabin by the Lake just.... was lacking. It must have had a very low budget because a fair amount of the movie must have been filmed with a regular video camera. So, within the same scene - you'll have some movie-quality camera shots AND simple video camera shots. It makes for a very odd blend! I think they should have found SOME way to not do the 'home video' type effect! I think it's worthwhile to see it IF you have seen the original CBTL because then you can compare and see the differences. But if you haven't seen the original CBTL.... you'll never want to see it if you see this one first! It will probably seem way too cheesy and turn you off from even caring about the original one.
agree: I completely agree with the review. The inconsistent quality of the filming can be distracting and take away from the overall viewing experience. It's important for a movie to maintain a consistent visual style to keep the audience engaged.
disagree: I disagree with the review. While the filming quality may have been inconsistent, it could have been a deliberate choice by the filmmakers to create a certain aesthetic or atmosphere. Sometimes, unconventional filming techniques can enhance the storytelling and make the movie more memorable.

agree: I completely agree with the review. While the movie may have some redeeming qualities, such as mild humor, the inconsistent filming techniques really detract from the overall viewing experience. It's disappointing when a film can't maintain a consistent visual style throughout.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. Despite its flaws, I found the movie to be entertaining and enjoyable. The mix of film and video footage added a unique and experimental element to the viewing experience, in my opinion. While it may not be a cinematic masterpiece, it still has its own charm and merits.

review: IF you are planning to see this movie, please reconsider. I don't usually post my comments about something I've seen on television, but this one was such a waste of my life that I needed to do something productive to get that bad taste out of my mouth. Critiquing this movie would take far too long as there are so many things wrong with it. I will just simply say, please do not ever see this movie. It was a complete waste of my time and it WILL be a waste of yours. Anyone that wrote a positive review of this movie is one of two things; utterly inept, or working for the company that produced it. Again, I guarantee that you will indeed regret seeing this movie!
agree: I completely agree with this review. It's rare for me to feel so strongly about a movie, but this one was truly a disappointment. The negative aspects far outweigh any redeeming qualities, and I would advise against wasting your time on it.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While everyone is entitled to their opinion, I believe that different viewers may have varying tastes and preferences when it comes to movies. It's possible that some people might find value or enjoyment in this film despite its flaws. I would suggest giving it a chance and forming your own opinion.

review: I saw this on the Sci-Fi channel. It came on right after the first one. For some reason this movie kept me interested. I don't know why, stop asking. ---SPOILERS--- Okay... It was cheesy how this guy got involved with the making of the movie. In the first movie, he had a 'reason' to kill people, but in this sequal, half of the killings/attempted killings were basicly for no reason. Stanley killed the director due to creative differences, he captured the co-writer due to creative differences, but what was the deal with trying to kill off the cast? No cast, no movie. He wanted it to 'look real when they died'? If this was supposed to be such a high budget movie, use the special effects, MAN. Of course like the first one, the captured girl gets away, and Stanley ends up getting messed up, and dissapears. Woooooow (sarcasm). This movie HAD potential. And the saddest thing of all... the really sad part... I would watch a 'Cabin by the Lake 3'. Only because I like Judd Nelson, and he's the only good part about this sequal.
agree: I agree with the reviewer that the sequel had potential but fell short in terms of plot development and character motivations. The killings and attempted killings seemed to lack clear reasoning, and the focus on trying to make them 'look real' instead of utilizing special effects was a missed opportunity. Judd Nelson's performance was a standout, but overall, the film could have been better executed.
disagree: I disagree with the reviewer's assessment that the sequel had potential. While the plot may have had some interesting elements, the lack of clear character motivations and the cheesy execution detracted from the overall viewing experience. Additionally, the reliance on clichés such as the captured girl escaping and the antagonist disappearing felt predictable and uninspired. Judd Nelson's performance may have been a highlight, but it wasn't enough to salvage the shortcomings of the film.

review: I watched Cabin by the Lake this afternoon on USA. Considering this movie was made for TV is was interesting enough to watch the sequel. So, I tune in for the airing this evening and was extremely disappointed. I knew I wouldn't like the movie, but I was not expecting to be perplexed by the use of DV (digital video). The movie would have been tolerable if it wasn't for these juxtaposed digital shots that seemed to come from nowhere. I expected the plot line to be tied in with these shots, but there seemed to be no logical explanation. (WARNING: THE FOLLOWING MAYBE A SPOILER!!!!) The open ending in Cabin by the Lake was acceptable, but the open ending on the sequel is ridiculous. I can only foresee Return of Return to The Cabin by the Lake being watch able is if the movie was shown up against nothing, but infomercials at 4 o'clock in the morning.
agree: I agree with the reviewer that the use of DV in the sequel was perplexing and seemed out of place. It detracted from the viewing experience and left me equally disappointed. The open ending in the sequel also felt unsatisfying and unnecessary, making it hard to see the appeal of a potential third installment.
disagree: While I understand the disappointment with the use of DV in the sequel and the open ending, I found the overall storyline and suspense in the movie to be engaging. The ambiguity of the ending left room for interpretation and speculation, which can be a compelling aspect of a film. Despite its flaws, I still found the sequel to be entertaining and worth watching.

review: 'Return to Cabin by the Lake' is a useless movie. The acting was not good and the plot wasn't even remotely interesting.
agree: I completely agree with this review. 'Return to Cabin by the Lake' failed to deliver on both acting and plot, making it a disappointing watch.
disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with this review. While 'Return to Cabin by the Lake' may not have lived up to the original, I found some redeeming qualities in the film, particularly in Judd Nelson's performance and the attempt to continue the story from the first installment.

review: A decent sequel, but does not pack the punch of the original. A murderous screenwriter(Judd Nelson) assumes new identities in order to direct his own novel CABIN BY THE LAKE. Still ruthless killing, but movie seems very tongue-in-cheek. Any humor is not of the funny kind. Total project seems to have the quality of a quickie and at times Nelson is way over the top. This movie is about a script being rewritten before going to the screen...this should have happened to this script.
agree: I agree with the review. While the sequel had potential, it fell short of capturing the essence of the original. Judd Nelson's performance, though intense, bordered on being too exaggerated, and the humor in the film did not quite hit the mark. The overall execution of the movie felt rushed and lacking in depth.
disagree: I disagree with the review. Despite not reaching the same level as the original, the sequel still managed to deliver an entertaining and suspenseful storyline. Judd Nelson's portrayal of the murderous screenwriter added a chilling intensity to the film, and the tongue-in-cheek approach provided a unique twist. While some aspects may have been over the top, they contributed to the overall dark and twisted atmosphere of the movie.

review: Return to Cabin by the Lake does not, in any way, stand up to the original. With only one main character (Stanley) returning for the sequel, the film is not even worth the 2 hours of your time. I am a huge fan of the first film, the storyline and acting were really good, but this is one movie that I will never again watch. It is basically equal to what the sequels to Urban Legends and Blair Witch were like, but with much worse acting. I've personally seen better acting in soap operas; it is so pitiful that you just have to laugh. I, in no way, recommend this movie to anyone; watching it will just detract from the first.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The lack of continuity with the original film and the poor acting in Return to Cabin by the Lake make it a disappointing sequel. It fails to capture the essence of the first movie and falls short in every aspect. I also found the acting to be subpar and not engaging, which significantly detracted from the viewing experience. I would not recommend this movie to anyone who enjoyed the original, as it does not live up to its predecessor.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While Return to Cabin by the Lake may not reach the same level as the original, I believe it still has some merit as a standalone film. The return of the character Stanley provides a sense of continuity, and the storyline, although not as strong as the first movie, still offers some entertainment value. While the acting may not be top-notch, I don't think it's as terrible as described in the review. Overall, I think the movie can be enjoyed for what it is, even if it doesn't surpass the original.

review: This was PURE CRAP! The whole Movie within a Movie crap. BAD STAY AWAY!
agree: I completely agree with this review. The concept of movies within a movie can be confusing and detract from the overall viewing experience.
disagree: I disagree with this review. While the movie within a movie concept may not be everyone's cup of tea, it can add an interesting layer of complexity and meta-narrative to the story.

review: I saw this movie recently because a friend brought it with him from NYC. After 30 minutes, I said to him,' You've got to be kidding. Is this some sort of joke?' He thought it was good. I told him that I thought it was probably one of the silliest movies ever made. 'What was it supposed to be?' I asked. 'A propaganda movie made for children?' The plot is stupid. The acting is the worst ever for most of the principals and frankly people who look at this sort of tripe and think it has anything to do with life, love or even afterlife, of which it offers an incredibly idiotic view...need some psychiatric help. Please, if someone tries to get you to stick this in your DVD or Video player, consider it like you would a virus introduced into your computer...it won't destroy your player but it will destroy your evening. If they had made Razzies in the '40s, this would have won in every category. (PS. It also goes under the dubious sobriquet of 'Stairway to Heaven.')
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie sounds like a complete disaster with a nonsensical plot, terrible acting, and a misguided attempt at portraying deep themes. It's understandable why the reviewer found it to be one of the silliest movies ever made. It's disappointing when a film fails to deliver on any meaningful level and instead leaves the audience feeling like their time was wasted.
disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with this review. While everyone is entitled to their opinion, it seems like the reviewer may have missed the intended purpose or charm of the movie. Sometimes films that are unconventional or delve into abstract themes can be polarizing, but that doesn't necessarily mean they are without merit. It's possible that the movie was aiming for a different kind of storytelling that didn't resonate with this particular viewer.

review: Despite a decent first season, this series never came close to realizing its potential. Set as a prequel to the original 'Star Trek' series, it was doomed almost from the start by an executive producer, Rick Berman, who felt compelled to artificially limit and constrict the definition of what a 'Star Trek' series could be. The actual show-runner, Brannon Braga, didn't help matters by his uninspired and tired rehashing of previous Trek episodes and careless disregard of the franchise's internal mythology. Never have I seen a series that so consistently did a disservice to a cast of talented actors last so long. Unfortunately, it appears as if Berman and Braga have succeeded in convincing the higher-ups at Paramount that 'Enterprise' suffered from 'franchise fatigue' and that its core audience was driven off.
agree: I completely agree with this review. 'Enterprise' had so much potential but was ultimately held back by the limitations imposed by the producers and showrunner. The lack of innovation and the repetitive nature of the episodes made it difficult for the show to stand out in a landscape where viewers were demanding more sophisticated and engaging content.
disagree: I disagree with the notion that 'Enterprise' was a complete failure. While it may not have lived up to the high standards set by its predecessors, the show still had its moments and managed to attract a dedicated fan base. The criticism of the producers and showrunner may be valid, but there were still aspects of the series that were enjoyable and engaging for fans of the 'Star Trek' franchise.

review: Anybody who has ever been a fan of the original series, or even has a clue about the storyline should be embarrassed by this series. The Borg does not come around until Q brings the Enterprise to the Gamma sector, the Klingons are NEVER seen until Kirk encounters them, the NCC-1701 was the FIRST ship to carry the Enterprise name....need I go on? Berman and Pilliar have made a mockery of Gene Roddenberry's creation. After he died, they only saw $$$$ and just went their own way. No wonder Majel Barrett was in every single episode of star trek until this series. I don't blame her for not being involved with this mess. Poor Bakula. He's a great actor, as are the entire cast. I like them all, but the storyline is tragic and ignores all of the precedents set by the original series. Just check the ratings. I think more people watched Deep Space 9 (which was untimely canceled).
agree: I completely agree with this review. As a fan of the original series, I was disappointed by the disregard for established canon and the blatant departure from Gene Roddenberry's vision. The creators seemed more focused on profit than honoring the legacy of Star Trek.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While there are valid points about the inconsistencies with the original series, I believe that Star Trek: Enterprise still had its own merits and provided a fresh perspective on the Star Trek universe. The cast, including Scott Bakula, delivered strong performances, and the show had its own unique storytelling elements that appealed to many viewers.

review: Okay first of all, I didn't sit down to watch the premier of a 'Star Trek' Series to see a cowboy flying around in space. this is how a normal Enterprise episode works 1 Archer finds a nebula or something along the lines of that and wants to take a closer look but it might destroy the ship. 2 he sends a shuttle into the nebula and and the shuttle get damaged... in all of the episodes I have seen, all of the problems are happening because of Archer's stupid mistakes. Oh and did you see the preview of one episode showing Archer and T'pol kissing?!?!?!?!?!?!? I was planning to watch that episode but after that I totally gave up on Enterprise and turned to TV right off. Come on!!!! This is star trek!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Also what was with the banana slug?? In one episode, Hoshi had a banana slug but had to leave it behind for some stupid reason. Okay fine, little dumb to bring your pet slug in space but whatever. Okay that was what I thought until they left it on a desert planet!!!!! A BANANA SLUG CANNOT LIVE IN A DESERT!!!! How dumb are these writers Anyways, just saying if Enterprise is on DON'T WATCH IT!!!!!
agree: I completely understand your frustration with the direction 'Enterprise' took in deviating from the traditional 'Star Trek' formula. The cowboy-like portrayal of Archer and the romantic subplot between him and T'Pol may have felt out of place for fans expecting a more exploration-focused narrative. The mishandling of the banana slug subplot also seemed like a strange choice that detracted from the overall credibility of the show. It's disappointing when a beloved franchise like 'Star Trek' fails to live up to its established standards.
disagree: While I acknowledge your disappointment with the changes in 'Enterprise,' I believe that the series attempted to bring a fresh perspective to the 'Star Trek' universe. By introducing new character dynamics and exploring different storytelling approaches, the show aimed to appeal to a broader audience and evolve the franchise. While not every creative decision may have resonated with fans, it's important to appreciate the effort to innovate and take risks in a long-running series like 'Star Trek.' Each iteration brings its own unique elements, and 'Enterprise' should be commended for trying to break new ground.

review: I'm not a huge Star Trek fan, but I was looking forward to this. I was intrigued by the pre-hype descriptions of the Enterprise, its cramped-submarine styling and rough-edged technology compared to the Treks we are used to. I didn't see anything all that interesting in this pilot. I found the plot to be convoluted and confusing. I will admit that I did like some of the character development - the depictions of the humans as an 'adolescent' species ready to outgrow their britches was entertaining. And that Vulcan babe had one hell of an incredible rack. But I don't think I'm going to get hooked on this series. 3/10
agree: I agree with the reviewer that the plot of the pilot was convoluted and confusing. It's important for a series to have a clear and engaging storyline to keep viewers interested.
disagree: I disagree with the reviewer's assessment that there wasn't anything interesting in the pilot. While the plot may have been confusing, the character development and unique take on the humans as an 'adolescent' species show potential for an intriguing series.

review: The earlier part of the film was rather enjoyable but towards the end it became trite. Although Turturro is an actor I generally like, his Luzhin often resembled a bad Rain Man impression and the portrayal of the genius as a semi-autistic man was annoying. Overall it seems as if this film is trying too hard and ends up looking pompous in spite of mostly fine performances.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The beginning of the film had promise, but as it progressed, it lost its charm and became cliché. Turturro's portrayal of Luzhin was disappointing and felt like a caricature rather than a nuanced character. The attempt to depict genius as semi-autistic came across as lazy and unoriginal. The film did indeed feel pretentious and failed to deliver on its potential.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I acknowledge that the film may have had some flaws, I found Turturro's performance as Luzhin to be captivating and nuanced. His portrayal added depth to the character and brought a unique perspective to the story. The depiction of genius as semi-autistic could be seen as a fresh take on the trope, adding complexity to the narrative. Despite some shortcomings, I believe the film succeeded in delivering a thought-provoking and engaging experience.

review: A movie that attempts to be far smarter than its makers are capable of producing. The movie twists and turns through myriad plot 'surprises' at a desperate attempt to keep the audience guessing, puncturing the 'plot' with steamy scenes they thought would help it along. James Belushi is involved in this pseudo-intellectual attempt and just sleepwalks through the movie. The same applies for the other 'actors'. The plot is quite silly and tacky, which in itself is not such a crime, but towards the end, the tremendous plot twists get very tiresome and boring. However, the movie does manage to generate some interest in the middle. In all, worth a lazy watch on a really boring day, but don't fret if you miss this one. A rather lame 4!
agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie indeed tries too hard to be clever and ends up falling flat. The plot twists become exhausting, and the inclusion of steamy scenes feels forced and unnecessary. The performances, including James Belushi's, lack depth and passion, making the whole viewing experience quite underwhelming. While there may be some moments of interest in the middle, overall, the film fails to deliver on its ambitious goals.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have its flaws, I found the intricate plot twists and surprises to be engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat. The inclusion of steamy scenes added a layer of intrigue to the story, and I appreciated the attempt to create a complex narrative. James Belushi's performance, though subdued, fit the tone of the movie well. The film may not be perfect, but it offers a unique viewing experience that is worth a watch, especially for those looking for something different.

review: If you can imagine Mickey Mouse as a New York street pimp, or John Wayne as a Communist spy, then you might believe Pat Boone as a juvenile delinquent on his uncle's farm in Kentucky and you could conceivably enjoy this movie. This film is so stupid that it isn't even campy for a mid 1950s sexless love story. And the problem is that Hollywood made such a big deal about Pat Boone's refusal to kiss a woman not his wife on screen before its release that the audience knows he won't kiss Shirley Jones so you cannot build any anticipation for the 'screen consummation' of their love. It's sort of like watching a western in which the cowboys don't have guns. The story is pointless. Even the title song is sung with pained enthusiasm. April Love belongs in the worst film bargain bin along with Ishtar and Plan 9 from Outer Space.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The premise of the movie sounds absurd and the lack of chemistry between the leads due to the no-kissing rule takes away any potential for emotional investment from the audience. The overall execution seems to be lacking, making it difficult to find any redeeming qualities in this film.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the concept may sound unconventional, sometimes movies that push boundaries can be entertaining in their own way. Pat Boone's portrayal as a juvenile delinquent on a farm could offer a unique perspective, and the restrictions placed on the romantic scenes could add a layer of tension and anticipation. Additionally, the comparison to Ishtar and Plan 9 from Outer Space may be too harsh, as every film has its own merits and audience appeal.

review: I really wanted to like this western, being a fan of the genre and a fan of 'Buffalo Bill,' 'Wild Bill Hickok,' and 'Calamity Jane,' all of whom are in this story! Add to the mix Gary Cooper as the lead actor, and it sounded great. The trouble was.....it wasn't. I found myself looking at my watch just 40 minutes into this, being bored to death. Jean Arthur's character was somewhat annoying and James Ellison just did not look like nor act like 'Buffalo Bill.' Cooper wasn't at his best, either, sounding too wooden. This was several years before he hit his prime as an actor. In a nutshell, his western shot blanks. Head up the pass and watch another oater because most of 'em were far better than this one.
agree: I completely agree with this review. As a fan of the western genre and the historical figures featured in the film, I had high hopes for it. However, I also found the pacing to be slow and the performances lacking. Jean Arthur's character was indeed grating, and the portrayal of 'Buffalo Bill' fell short. Gary Cooper's performance felt lackluster compared to his later work. Overall, I was disappointed by the film and would recommend seeking out other, more engaging westerns.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While I understand the criticisms of the film's pacing and character portrayals, I found the historical context and the presence of iconic figures like 'Buffalo Bill,' 'Wild Bill Hickok,' and 'Calamity Jane' to be intriguing. Gary Cooper's performance, though not his best, still carried the film with his presence. I believe that despite its flaws, the film offers a unique perspective on the Wild West and is worth a watch for fans of the genre.

review: I have always admired Susan Sarandon for her integrity and honesty in her private life as well as her talents as an actor. I therefor found it strange that she would appear in a film that so distorted that facts. Her character's rescue from the South Pole was done by a Canadian charter company from Edmonton, Alberta flying a Canadian designed and built Twin Otter aircraft. The trip had been turned down by the US Airforce, Navy and Coast Guard as beyond their capabilities. The same company staged a similar rescue a few years later to bring out a man from the South Pole base. I feel that the film fairly represented a very gripping subject and documented a very courageous woman facing a frightening task. I fail to see why the producers would find it necessary ignore the bravery of the rescue pilots and show the rescue plane as a USAF Hercules.
agree: I completely agree with the reviewer's point about the importance of accurately portraying the real-life events and individuals involved in the rescue mission. It's disappointing when filmmakers take liberties with historical facts, especially when it diminishes the contributions of the actual heroes who were involved in the rescue. Susan Sarandon's talents as an actor could have been better utilized in a film that stayed true to the bravery and sacrifices of the Canadian rescue pilots.
disagree: While I understand the reviewer's concern about the inaccuracies in the film's portrayal of the rescue mission, I believe that artistic license is often taken in movies based on true events. The filmmakers may have chosen to alter certain details for dramatic effect or narrative purposes, rather than to intentionally disregard the bravery of the Canadian rescue pilots. Susan Sarandon's performance and the overall storytelling may still have merit, even if the historical accuracy is not perfect.

review: Superb recreation of the base in Antarctica where the real events of the film took place. Other than that, libelous!, scandalous! Filmed in Canada; presumably by a largely Canadian crew and cast. I caught the last half of this film recently on Global television here in Canada. Nothing much to say other than how thoroughly appalled I was at what a blatant piece of American historical revisionist propaganda it is; and starring Susan Sarandon of all people! I can only assume that Canadian born director Roger Spottiswoode was coerced to make the USAF the heroes of the film when in fact the real rescuers where a small private airline based in Calgary; Kenn Borek Air.
agree: I agree with the review that the film was a blatant piece of American historical revisionist propaganda. It is disappointing to see the real rescuers, like Kenn Borek Air, not being properly represented in the film.
disagree: I disagree with the review's criticism of the film being libelous and scandalous. While the portrayal of the USAF as the heroes may be inaccurate, it is not necessarily libelous. The film may have taken creative liberties for dramatic effect, which is common in historical dramas.

review: OK first of all the video looks like it was filmed in the 80s I was shocked to find out it was released in 2001. Secondly the plot was all over the place, right off the bat the story is confusing. Had there been some brief prologue or introduction the story would've been better. Also I appreciate fantasy but this film was too much. It was bizarre and badly filmed. The scenes did not flow smoothly and the characters were odd. It was hard to follow and maybe it was the translation but it was even hard to understand. I love Chinese epic films but if you're looking for a Chinese epic fantasy film i would recommend the Promise (visually stunning, the plot is interesting and good character development) not this film. Beware you will be disappointed.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The film's outdated visuals and confusing plot made it a disappointing watch. The lack of a proper introduction and the excessive fantasy elements only added to the confusion. I also found the characters to be strange and the overall flow of the scenes to be disjointed. I would also recommend The Promise over this film for a better Chinese epic fantasy experience.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the film may have a unique visual style reminiscent of the 80s, I found it to be a deliberate artistic choice that added to the overall charm of the movie. The complex plot and fantasy elements may not be for everyone, but I appreciated the creativity and boldness in storytelling. The characters' eccentricities and the non-linear scenes only enhanced the mysterious and otherworldly atmosphere of the film. In my opinion, this movie offers a refreshing take on the Chinese epic fantasy genre and is worth a watch for those looking for something different.

review: Zu Warriors most definitely should've been an animated series because as a movie it's like watching an old anime on acid. The movie just starts out of nowhere and people just fly around fighting with metal wings and other stupid weapons until this princess sacrifices herself for her lover on a cloud or something. Whether this princess is a god or an angel is beyond me but soon enough this flying wind bad guy comes in and kills her while the guy with the razor wings fights some other mystical God/Demon/Wizard thing. The plot line is either not there or extremely hard to follow you need to be insanely intelligent to get this movie. The plot soon follows this Chinese mortal who is called upon by this god to fight the evil flying, princess killing bad guy and soon we have a very badly choreographed Uwe Boll like fight scene complete with terrible martial arts on a mountain or something. Even the visuals are weird some might say they are stunning and colorful but i'm going to say they are blurry and acid trip like (yes that's a word!). I watched it both dubbed and with subtitles and both were equally bad and hard to understand....who am i kidding i didn't understand it at all. It felt like i was watching episode 30 of some 1980's anime and completely missed how the story began or like i started reading a comic series of 5 at number 4 because i had no clue how this thing started where it was going or how it would end i was lost the entire time. I can honestly say this was one of the worst film experiences ever it was like watching Inu-Yasha at episode 134 drunk...yeah that's right you don't know what the hell is going on. Don't waste your brain trying to figure this out.
agree: I completely agree with this review. 'Zu Warriors' was a confusing mess of a movie with a convoluted plot and bizarre visuals. It felt like trying to make sense of a jumbled anime episode while on a psychedelic trip. The lack of coherent storytelling and poorly executed fight scenes made it a frustrating viewing experience. I also found it difficult to follow the storyline and felt lost throughout the film. This movie would have been better suited as an animated series where the fantastical elements could have been explored in a more cohesive manner.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review of 'Zu Warriors'. While I acknowledge that the movie had a complex

review: This is not so much film as big budget children's television. As far as I can tell, the villain is a giant swarm of chocolate covered espresso beans. This theory seems to be verified by the fact that the subtitles refer to it as 'Insomnia'. When it's first mentioned that a civilization had been wiped out by insomnia, I thought 'Wow! A nihilistic martial arts film!' but no such luck. Although you have to consider it experimental cinema when the villain is strangled by an old man's long, white eyebrows. Zu Warriors makes exactly the same amount of sense whether the subtitles are on or off. That's not a good sign. I found the special effects to be somewhere between Ray Harryhausen and Xena: Warrior Princess. Primitive.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The film's bizarre plot and low-quality special effects make it feel more like a cheesy children's TV show than a serious martial arts film. The villain being a swarm of chocolate-covered espresso beans and the strange subplot about insomnia only add to the confusion and lack of coherence in the movie. The comparison to Xena: Warrior Princess in terms of special effects is spot on, as the visuals feel outdated and unimpressive.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While Zu Warriors may have a unique and unconventional storyline, it offers a refreshing departure from traditional martial arts films. The creative choice of having a villain like a swarm of chocolate-covered espresso beans adds a whimsical and imaginative element to the movie. The special effects, though not on par with modern standards, contribute to the film's charm and nostalgic appeal, reminiscent of classic fantasy films like those by Ray Harryhausen.

review: Watched this on DVD in original language with English subs. Either the subtitling was very poor or the actual dialog doesn't make much of story and give any character development. There are quite a few HK stars in this but the movie doesn't need their presence to make it better or worse. It's just bad. The bright and colorful scenes done in CG are attractive for the sheer colors and brilliance but it can get overwhelming before long. If anything this makes me think of a child's movie with its nonstop barrage of cg, fight scenes, and crap plot. I'm certain I grasped what took place in the film but the whole delivery of the story was rather lousy.
agree: I completely agree with this review. The subtitling or dialogues did not contribute to the story or character development. The presence of HK stars did not add value to the movie, and the excessive use of CG scenes became overwhelming. The film felt like a chaotic mix of fight scenes and a weak plot, resembling a child's movie rather than a well-crafted film.
disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the subtitling may have been lacking, I found the bright and colorful CG scenes to be visually appealing and engaging. The presence of HK stars added a certain charm to the movie, and I believe the nonstop action and fight scenes added to the entertainment value. Despite any flaws in the delivery of the story, I still found the overall experience enjoyable and entertaining.
